componenttext: Our next question comes from David Deckelbaum of KeyBanc.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dan, can you give any color, I guess, can you talk about exiting this year, I think at 2 Bcf a day gross, and I guess you'd be ramping onto that first quarter there, is the thought, I guess, you'd be basically at your capacity almost in 1Q in terms of del
componenttext: Dan, can you give any color, I guess, can you talk about exiting this year, I think at 2 Bcf a day gross, and I guess you'd be ramping onto that first quarter there, is the thought, I guess, you'd be basically at your capacity almost in 1Q in terms of deliverability, and you'd more or less hold that number kind of flattish throughout the rest of '17, unless there is some other release capacity out there?

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We think that -- and I'll let Jeff talk kind of about the market and how we might grow into the market a little bit and focus on '17 pre-infrastructure buildout. But when we look at the exit at 2 Bcf, again, we're measuring our growth at this point i
componenttext: Yes. We think that -- and I'll let Jeff talk kind of about the market and how we might grow into the market a little bit and focus on '17 pre-infrastructure buildout. But when we look at the exit at 2 Bcf, again, we're measuring our growth at this point in time. We have cash on the balance sheet, we have the ability to ramp up as you might suspect, but we think prior to, again, getting closer to the in-service of the infrastructure, we think it is a benefit to keep this in-basin dynamic of restricted growth on the 3 pipes and the supply side in somewhat of a balance. But we do see it relatively -- and our plan is to stay relatively flat from an exit volume of 2 Bcf, and that's what got to my measured growth comment in '17 of 5% to 10%. Jeff, do you want to make any comments about kind of the dynamics of the market up there right now?

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. David, if you recall, we've been to 2 Bcf before, 2 Bcf a day is not a stretch in terms of moving gas and finding capacity, expanding our existing markets and our customer basis. Right now, and we've talked a little bit about this on the first call
componenttext: Sure. David, if you recall, we've been to 2 Bcf before, 2 Bcf a day is not a stretch in terms of moving gas and finding capacity, expanding our existing markets and our customer basis. Right now, and we've talked a little bit about this on the first call about the availability of excess firm capacity in the marketplace in the secondary market, we look at that every day. We're pretty happy we didn't pull the trigger back in February on a number of these capacity deals. Quite frankly, the rates keep improving. The options keep getting better, the volumes are more to our liking. The durations are more to our liking. And so we're watching this capacity release market very closely and as we get further into the year, we find that there's more producers or I should call them producers, shippers that aren't using their capacity. It's quite dynamical, it's something that we think, at some point, we will pick up some additional capacity just bridges the cap -- excuse me, bridges the gap over to closer to 2018. So a lot of options right now and I think really good options to improve net backs.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016

componenttext: I appreciate that color, Jeff. So it sounds like there's some potential, I guess, to see some release capacity in '17 then?

componenttext: Yes. Our desire is to underpin some of our volumes with the hedge. We continue to look at the market and again, trying to get a feel for a forward curve. We think that the opportunity the place hedges in a range that have been in the recent past, we think that opportunity still exists out in front of us, and we think actually the opportunity could maybe improve from where some of the hedges have been placed behind us.

componenttext: Yes. We'll be opportunistic. I can't -- the market, as you know, and we all know, is very dynamic and hard to predict with accuracy, but at least it is our consensus with our hedge committee that we can still protect our volumes into '17, between now and the end of the year.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Holly, this is, of course, a sensitive subject. First of all, we're very, very happy to be with our partners in the power generation business. Diversifying our commodity a little bit more to power from gas and it'd be in the local [indiscernible] ar
componenttext: Okay. Holly, this is, of course, a sensitive subject. First of all, we're very, very happy to be with our partners in the power generation business. Diversifying our commodity a little bit more to power from gas and it'd be in the local [indiscernible] area, as you mentioned. It's our benefit to link some power pricing to our gas prices. So the benefit of these 2 particular projects are unique, and that as Dan mentioned in the speech, that literally no FTEs that we had to buy to get there, so all of a sudden, [indiscernible] were $0.50 to $0.60 better than having to purchase long-term liability FTE to get to these power plants. That said, the pricing for the power plants, a small portion of each one of these plants is local pricing across power plants, generally [indiscernible], so small percentage of that load is related to local gas, daily pricing. However, what we've done is set arbitrary [indiscernible] and caps under the agreement that protect Cabot and also protect power generator. And we fluctuate between those floors and caps based on [indiscernible] power prices or at least a percent of [indiscernible] power price. And that enables essentially the generator and for Cabot to win, just a great structure for everyone.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016

componenttext: Okay, is there like a minimum volume if the plant doesn't dispatch? Do you still get paid?

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Keep in mind, these are brand-new, high-efficiency plants. Their run time in the first 5 years will be at least 95% to 96%. So you have a couple of days of maintenance each year. Recall too that we have a fuel manager between us and the power generator, a
componenttext: Keep in mind, these are brand-new, high-efficiency plants. Their run time in the first 5 years will be at least 95% to 96%. So you have a couple of days of maintenance each year. Recall too that we have a fuel manager between us and the power generator, and a fuel manager's role is to continue to purchase gas and move gas during days or an hour or whatever the case may be, that the plant may not be operating. We would fully expect these plants to operate at a very, very high load rate, at least through the first 5 to 7 years.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Holly, this is Jeff. One more thought on that. These projects sometimes [indiscernible] out of control. In other words, when the maintenance is done and sometimes, it extends longer than those [indiscernible], but in this case, the majority of the mai
componenttext: And Holly, this is Jeff. One more thought on that. These projects sometimes [indiscernible] out of control. In other words, when the maintenance is done and sometimes, it extends longer than those [indiscernible], but in this case, the majority of the maintenance that we're experiencing, on Transco in particular, is quite, frankly, just pipe replacement. We're almost through it. In fact, it ends on July 30.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Charles Meade from Johnson Rice.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Charles Meade from Johnson Rice.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd like to explore a little bit more the -- your opportunities to be -- or your intent to be opportunistic in 1Q '17 and how that interacts with your decision to accelerate your completion base here in the back half of the year. Is this the sort of thing
componenttext: I'd like to explore a little bit more the -- your opportunities to be -- or your intent to be opportunistic in 1Q '17 and how that interacts with your decision to accelerate your completion base here in the back half of the year. Is this the sort of thing where you're committing to a delivering more volumes in 1Q '17, anticipating some better realizations there? Or is this more about you building the optionality to perhaps capture just a week's worth of high local pricing in the event of a cold winter?

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We're not really doing for just a short-term grab, Charles. If you look at our plan that we're going to present in October to our board and you look at -- I obviously have the benefit of looking out a little late with the draft we have currently, and
componenttext: Yes. We're not really doing for just a short-term grab, Charles. If you look at our plan that we're going to present in October to our board and you look at -- I obviously have the benefit of looking out a little late with the draft we have currently, and if you look at that build that we have out in front of us and you go back to the infrastructure projects that we've highlighted here and there's other things that Jeff is working on, we have to start at some point in time to plan, schedule in an efficient way, in the most efficient way getting out ahead of a ramp of almost 2 Bcf a day additional production. And if you think about that, you say real quick, it's not that difficult. Phil Stalnaker sitting here beside me and he squirms everyday when we look at the end of '18, which is not that far out in front of us, and it's his group that is less than 100 people out there and -- but with some excellent rock, his job is to manage the economic growth of our operation out there, and to build into this infrastructure. Now what, ideally, we were hoping with happen is, Constitution would have come on by now, and as everybody knows the pains of that process, but we've stacked these other infrastructure projects in line now. But the good news is they're all going to happen, but they're going to happen kind of on top of each other and contemporaneous, which does require us to start out ahead of that ramp-up in a way that would have some of the decisions we're making today in preparation for what we expect to be able to build into as these projects come online. So we like the dynamics of where the market is and we certainly like the better pricing we see. For example, to your point, in the first quarter of '17, that's all good, and certainly, we'll be in that space to benefit from it, but we were looking at more of a long-term build and getting up to the 3.5, 4 Bcf production range towards the end of '18.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: The Atlantic Sunrise project is a big project in anyone's eyes. The scope is large, and the good news there is 850,000 a day of new capacity with a brand-new pipe coming into our backyard but also 100% on the 850,000 a day of gas and sold to 2 very good m
componenttext: The Atlantic Sunrise project is a big project in anyone's eyes. The scope is large, and the good news there is 850,000 a day of new capacity with a brand-new pipe coming into our backyard but also 100% on the 850,000 a day of gas and sold to 2 very good markets in -- to Cove Point LNG with Sumitomo, and of course, [indiscernible] in the DC area. Absolutely, that's a standout project for us. As we move down the list, it's interesting that the next 4 projects that we have and in total, these all add up to about 1.5 Bcf a day, just make one comment, the good news is on the 1.5, all the 50,000 a day is already pace and sold to very good markets. So in terms of ranking or just how excited we are about these projects over the next 18 months, both power plant facilities are way up there on the list, good markets, no transport, ratable burns, I mean, it's very exciting. The TGP Orion project of 135,000 a day, again, 100% of that gas is sold, is going [indiscernible] to a power plant that operate in the southern part of New Jersey. Great pricing there. And then the PennEast Pipeline, that pipeline's 1 Bcf a day, and we have 100,000 sold already and 50,000 of capacity, but keep in mind, the impact of a PennEast or impact of Atlantic Sunrise, what that's going to do to basis differentials on Transco. As you start moving, a lot of gas off that pipe, a lot of gas from our supplier, where our expectations are that pricing raises differentials both on Tennessee and on Transco are going to improve. I mean, there's just no doubt in my mind. So not only do we have all these projects take away to the region, [indiscernible] all shifts, and in this case, we expect an upgrade to local pricing connected on these projects.

componenttext: We will continue to test, not only how tight we can get locations and Phil has a couple downspace opportunities or wells that we look at, but we'll also continue to explore with stage loading and spaces, spacing between clusters as part of our efforts to see how we can enhance the program. One of -- the July period for Cabot at our board meetings is opportunity for our geologist to stand before the board and talk about our exploration projects, ideas that we have and we do have some, and we did present several to our board on Wednesday. But one of the things also the technical group has done in the North has -- is taking a step back. We have a huge database, as you can surmise, and look at the entire space and determine what we might do different with a blank piece of paper, starting over to try to look at all the different aspects, all the way from planning areas, steering, penetration rates, how we initiate fracs, how we bring back the wells, all of that is being scrutinized in a project orientated fashion that I imagine Phil would come back and discuss at a later date. headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right, Ericsson, I don't have any additional remarks. But just to reemphasize that we are extremely pleased with the operational side of our program. We are building into the infrastructure buildout, starting the early stages of some excitement about
componenttext:
All right, Ericsson, I don't have any additional remarks. But just to reemphasize that we are extremely pleased with the operational side of our program. We are building into the infrastructure buildout, starting the early stages of some excitement about seeing some tangible results in that area and I think it's going to be fun for our operating group to now diligently start being able to use their talents, secure the services and equipment and start a very diligent process and building these significant volumes. If you look out there in the space, I don't know if any other company that has an opportunity and the rock to be able -- and the balance sheet to be able to grow production, double production in the next couple of years and have the benefits to get shareholders that Cabot does. So thank you for your interest, and we are excited about presenting our 5-year plan to our board in October and we do anticipate offering may be a little bit more color, either on October or February, we haven't made that call of a little bit longer outlook for what Cabot has to offer. 
So thanks again, and look forward to the next quarterly call.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016

componenttext:
Good day, and welcome to the Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation's Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call and Webcast. [Operator Instructions] Please note, this event is being recorded. 
I would now like to turn the conference over to Mr. Dan Dinges, Chairman, President and CEO. Please go ahead.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Ericson, and thank you all for joining this morning for Cabot's Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. I have today with me several members of the executive team. Before we start, let me do say that the standard boilerplate regarding forward-look
componenttext:
Thank you, Ericson, and thank you all for joining this morning for Cabot's Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. I have today with me several members of the executive team. 
Before we start, let me do say that the standard boilerplate regarding forward-looking statements included in this morning's press release applies to my comments on today's call. 
Cabot's second quarter results highlight our ability to deliver production growth while also generating positive free cash flow even in a low commodity price environment. We believe this characteristic sets us apart for most of our industry peers. 
Cabot averaged 1.67 Bcfe per day of net production during the quarter, an increase of 10% compared to the second quarter of 2015. This increase was driven by 14% increase in our Marcellus production volumes as compared to the prior year comparable quarter. Despite a realized natural gas price of only $1.63 per Mcf, we generated positive free cash flow for the quarter, and we anticipate that the company will be able to deliver a more meaningful level of free cash flow during the second half of the year based on current strip prices.
Natural gas realizations did improve by 9% sequentially as compared to the first quarter of the year, due in part to a significant improvement in local basis differential during the quarter. Before the impact of derivatives, Cabot's realizations were $0.40 below the average NYMEX settle price of $1.95 during the quarter as compared to $0.60 below the average NYMEX settlement price in the first quarter. While basis differentials have subsequently widened in the third quarter due to a significant increase in the NYMEX prices, the good news is that we are forecasting much higher price realizations during the second half of the year, resulting in more free cash flow for the year than originally forecast. This increase in expected cash flows has allowed for the introduction of a second frac crew in the Marcellus for a portion of the second half of the year, which will help give us a jump start on 2017 production. 
Using the current 5-year forward curve for Leidy Line, which is a good proxy for the most punitive pricing a portion of our Marcellus production receives, our well level internal rate of returns are over 100%, and our PV-10s are approximately $14 million. I cannot think of another asset that generates those economics in the current price environment, and therefore, we feel extremely comfortable about slightly increasing our levels of operating activity beginning with this additional frac crew. 
The second quarter results also demonstrate our continued emphasis on cost control, with unit costs declining by 12% compared to the prior year comparable quarter and 2% compared to the first quarter of this year. We have now delivered a sequential decline in unit costs for 12 of the last 13 quarters and expect this trend to continue, further improving our industry-leading cost structure. 
Our balance sheet remains extremely strong, with over $500 million of cash on hand and a net debt to EBITDAX ratio of only 1.8x at quarter-end. Based on our current forecast, we anticipate delevering between now and year-end, while our current liquidity of $2.2 billion should continue to improve given our outlook for positive free cash flow in the second half of the year. This financial flexibility will serve as well as we formulate our plans for 2017 and beyond. 
In the Marcellus, we continue to operate one drilling rig, and as mentioned, have recently added a second frac crew to accelerate the completion of our DUC inventory, which will allow for an acceleration of production in the first quarter of 2017. 
During the quarter, we drilled 7 wells, completed 8 wells, and placed 12 wells on production. The average lateral length for the 7 wells drilled during the second quarter was approximately 7,000 feet. However, given that all of the wells, 100% of the wells we placed on production year-to-date, were drilled in '15, and the average lateral length was a little bit shorter and closer to 6,000 feet. The good news is that we should continue improvements in capital efficiency in 2017 as we've began placing on production the longer lateral wells from this year program. 
On the production front, we averaged approximately 1.54 Bcf per day of net production for the Marcellus during the quarter, which was slightly below the midpoint of our expectations due to unscheduled downtime related to infrastructure maintenance in the region. Had we not experienced this downtime, we would have eclipsed the high end of our production guidance range for the quarter. Unfortunately, July production volumes have also been impacted somewhat by outages on Transco for their majority of the month. However, we are confident that we'll be able to keep production levels flat for the second quarter based on our plans on placing 12 wells on production during the third quarter. 
On the operations front, our drilling team continues to capture more efficiency gains, which was evident by new record for drilling days during the quarter of approximately 9 days for spud to TD and 13 days for spud to spud. We also drilled our longest Marcellus well to date with a total measured depth of over 18,000 feet and a lateral length of over 10,000 feet, which is scheduled to be completed in 2017.
A brief comment on our Eagle Ford shale. Despite a significant reduction in our Eagle Ford operating activity, including no wells drilled and only 3 wells completed during the quarter, our oil volumes for the second quarter exceeded our guidance due to outperformance from the newer wells that were placed on production. Given that our last Eagle Ford well was placed on production in May, we are not placing any wells on production during the third quarter. We are forecasting declines in our oil production volumes for the remainder of the year, which is in line with our original plan. At this point in time, based on our current outlook on oil prices, our plan is to continue to allocate a minimal amount of capital to our Eagle Ford assets, and instead, focus on arresting base declines, meeting our leasehold obligations and waiting for a slightly higher oil price environment before allocating any additional capital to this asset. 
I would highlight that even in today's prices, our returns in Eagle Ford far exceed our cost of capital. But given the much higher returns we see in the Marcellus, we believe the best place for additional capital today is in Susquehanna County. 
As you may all be aware, Cabot is directly involved with multiple pipeline ventures that focus on our growth opportunities over the next several years. I would like to provide a few updates and comments on the progress of these important infrastructure projects since our last call. 
Regarding Constitution, our initial appellant brief was filed on July 12, 2016 with the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, including -- included in this brief is a very comprehensive summary of the issues we found regarding the New York DEC water quality application process, and additionally outlines the schedule for the appeal process. Together, this brief should answer the majority of your questions concerning Constitution. 
We have made progress as well with Atlantic Sunrise during early March. The FERC issued a scheduling notice for Atlantic Sunrise, and on May 5, 2016, issued the draft environmental impact statement. Our expectations are to receive the final environmental impact statement during October, and to remain on schedule for a late 2017 in service. 
For the Tennessee gas pipeline Orion project, the FERC also issued their scheduling notice for environmental review during June and indicated that the final environmental assessment would be issued by mid August, 2016. This $135 million per day project remains on schedule for a June 18 in-service date. 
Also of note was the recent issuance of the draft environmental impact statement by the FERC on the 1 Bcf a day PennEast project. The final EIS is scheduled for mid-December, and this project remains on schedule for late '18. As a reminder, Cabot has $150 million a day committed to the PennEast project. 
Moving on to our recent announcements of Lackawanna Energy Center power facility. We are very excited to be the exclusive provider of up to 240 million cubic foot a day to Pennsylvania's largest natural gas facility and one of the most efficient power plants in the U.S. Together with our previous announcement to provide 100% of the natural gas requirements to the Moxie Freedom plan, Cabot will be providing more than 400 million cubic foot a day to local demand projects. Both facilities are essentially tied into our gathering system, eliminating the need to commit to expensive long-term FT agreements. 
And our pricing terms, although confidential, provide very attractive rate of returns with netbacks that are expected to be materially better than our anticipated netbacks in the local region. Assuming a gross exit rate for this year of approximately 2 Bcf per day, we have line of sight to double our production to over 4 Bcf per day, assuming all of the announced projects are approved and built. 
For all the Constitution naysayers out there, while we're still extremely confident that the project is ultimately constructed even without Constitution volumes, we still have direct line of sight to have the ability to produce over 3.5 Bcf per day by the end of 2018, which is effectively double the production levels we average during the second quarter. Not to mention, our marketing team continues to evaluate additional projects that would all be incremental to the numbers I just discussed.
And our outlook comment. As a result of continued efficiency gains and incremental cost savings, the company plans to complete an additional 15 to 20 Marcellus wells during the second half of the year and will also incur an additional $20 million of capital. The production impact of accelerated Marcellus completions will not be realized until early 2017, therefore, we're leaving our current '16 production guidance unchanged. 
While our plan for '17 are still being evaluated and our official budget will not be announced until October, I can say that measured growth in the 5% to 10% range in '17 is a prudent and reasonable assumption. And based on today's outlook, we would generate even more positive free cash flow next year than we will this year. 
When you look at Cabot's story over the next several years, I see a company with a strong balance sheet that continues to get better, best-in-class economics that continue to improve, cash margins that are expected to almost double by 2018 at this current strip, a growth outlook that allows for a doubling of Marcellus production volumes once the majority of our infrastructure is in service and a significant level of free cash flow accumulated during the period of time, providing optionality for program acceleration, dividend enhancement, share buyback, balance sheet management, et cetera. 
Needless to say, the outlook for Cabot is certainly bright, and I look forward to providing more details about our long-term plans in October. 
Ericson, with that brief statement, I'll be more than happy to answer any questions.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from Neal Dingmann of SunTrust.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from Neal Dingmann of SunTrust.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Nice details, Dan. Say, Dan, a question for you. Given the single oil economics that you've discussed, seeing out there obviously a very, very positive, or 100%. Why not when you look at -- you're in -- look at that and you look at the inventory, why not
componenttext: Nice details, Dan. Say, Dan, a question for you. Given the single oil economics that you've discussed, seeing out there obviously a very, very positive, or 100%. Why not when you look at -- you're in -- look at that and you look at the inventory, why not bump production even more, given the efficiencies? And is it more about takeaway? Or are there other bottlenecks you're considering?

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's a great question, Neal, and we have that internal debate often. When you look at the macro market and you look at the volatility still out there in the macro market, even though there are volumes -- additional volumes we could move today, we do think
componenttext: It's a great question, Neal, and we have that internal debate often. When you look at the macro market and you look at the volatility still out there in the macro market, even though there are volumes -- additional volumes we could move today, we do think it's prudent to be rational into the market. We've seen NYMEX increased in the third quarter, beginning in the third quarter, but we've seen the differentials expand a little bit even though our realizations have improved over second quarter. We still think as we gain traction, continue to get regulatory approvals on the infrastructure build-out, we think it's prudent to be rational at this point in time until we see the infrastructure projects put in place, and at that particular time, be prepared for the ramp-up. And by doing so in concert with that build-out, we don't think it's going to create liabilities to the existing base and in the limited infrastructure we have.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016

componenttext: And then, Dan, I just want to hit on efficiencies real quick. You mentioned about 13 days spud to spud. Is that now what you guys -- is that just occasionally? What are you guys kind of look at now at sort of a typical spud to spud, given you've had some great value improvement on efficiencies?

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Okay, Neal. The differentials in the second quarter certainly improved, and a lot of that was related to the drop in NYMEX. We saw Henry Hub in the second quarter averaged about $0.95. And compared to the second quarter of '15, for example, it's $2.6
componenttext: Yes. Okay, Neal. The differentials in the second quarter certainly improved, and a lot of that was related to the drop in NYMEX. We saw Henry Hub in the second quarter averaged about $0.95. And compared to the second quarter of '15, for example, it's $2.64, and we saw about half differential this year compared to last year. And of course, for the rally during June on NYMEX going forward for the rest of the year, so our diffs definitely widened out a little bit. But we won't see the volatility all year long as we watch these storage injection numbers and watch the market tighten.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Drew Venker of Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Drew Venker of Morgan Stanley.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was hoping you can talk about what you're seeing in terms of acquisition opportunities. You have significant free cash flow generation what you think is there nowadays amongst your peers, though. Just would like to hear your thinking about that.
componenttext: I was hoping you can talk about what you're seeing in terms of acquisition opportunities. You have significant free cash flow generation what you think is there nowadays amongst your peers, though. Just would like to hear your thinking about that.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Drew, a good question. We get that M&A question because we do have such a strong balance sheet and great cash flow. We look at deals out there. We look at opportunities, and we try to stack them against what we have as our ongoing model. We put toget
componenttext: Yes, Drew, a good question. We get that M&A question because we do have such a strong balance sheet and great cash flow. We look at deals out there. We look at opportunities, and we try to stack them against what we have as our ongoing model. We put together -- or I should say -- or the process of putting together a 5-year model. We'll present this 5-year plan to our board in October. In discussions with that model, when you look at our organic program, what we are able to achieve with the assumptions that we placed in there on commodity pricing. And then we also look at the available opportunities out there and also just our own internal ideas of what we might be able to do different to enhance long-term shareholder value. And that's a continuing discussion we have in our board meeting, not only in every board meeting, but we also have an off-site meeting, many are aware, in September. That is a strategic discussion at the 30,000-foot level, the macro market, the movements in the market, strengths of the market, opportunities in the market to see how we can continue to enhance shareholder value. So we have not been an acquisitive company, but we have been a company that continues to evaluate the opportunities that are out there and the asset basis and/or, in some cases, the corporate companies that have possible needs and their future to do something different. So we haven't made any decisions, but we do evaluate the market.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dan, just to follow-up on that, I guess the -- part of what I'm curious about is with the rates return you can generate in the Marcellus, whether you really see much that's competitive with that on an acquisition front or if that's how you think about it.
componenttext: Dan, just to follow-up on that, I guess the -- part of what I'm curious about is with the rates return you can generate in the Marcellus, whether you really see much that's competitive with that on an acquisition front or if that's how you think about it. And as you've gone through the deal process, has there been anything that's come close to meeting those thresholds that you need to move forward with an acquisition?

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We have, I think, demonstrated with our plan, how we're running the company and what we have done and trying to rationalize our growth and measured growth is what we have provided. We do that because we are trying to maximize our return in a soft com
componenttext: Yes. We have, I think, demonstrated with our plan, how we're running the company and what we have done and trying to rationalize our growth and measured growth is what we have provided. We do that because we are trying to maximize our return in a soft commodity price environment, and we're certainly trying to look at the market in a macro sense to determine what we think best -- our input into the market and how we think that would best maintain the margins and strength of Cabot. So when you look at the M&A market, diversity is one of those areas that we discuss, not only geographic diversity, but also commodity diversity. We look at that in a way that compares what we have in our organic program, the risk of execution of our organic program and how we might be able to enhance the valuations, the return profile in our program if, in fact, we had a bolt-on, we had a new greenfield operation or we had a merge opportunity out there. And to your point, what we receive on a term profile with every dollar that Cabot invests, it does challenge us to look at the market out there, to look at other assets and to be able to say that we are prepared to displace any capital allocated to our Marcellus and allocate elsewhere. And when we don't get comfortable with that, in essence, dilution of that investment in that context, we do look at the infrastructure build-out, we know we have a significant growth profile coming for Cabot, and it's just around the corner. It's now not measured really in years. It's measured in months of when we're going to see that. So our focus is more internally, right now, to get our program lined up and to be prepared to grow into that market, double our production or greater and do that as efficiently as we can.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from David Deckelbaum of KeyBanc.
componenttext: Our next question comes from David Deckelbaum of KeyBanc.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dan, can you give any color -- I guess, you talked about exiting this year, I think, at 2 Bcf a day gross, and I guess you'd be ramping onto that first quarter there. Is the thought, I guess, you'd be basically at your capacity almost in 1Q in terms of de
componenttext: Dan, can you give any color -- I guess, you talked about exiting this year, I think, at 2 Bcf a day gross, and I guess you'd be ramping onto that first quarter there. Is the thought, I guess, you'd be basically at your capacity almost in 1Q in terms of deliverability, and you'd more or less hold that number kind of flattish throughout the rest of '17 unless there is some other release capacity out there?

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We think that the -- and I'll let Jeff talk kind of about the market and how we might grow into the market a little bit and focus on '17 pre-infrastructure build-out. But when we look at the exit at 2 Bcf, again, we're measuring our growth at this po
componenttext: Yes. We think that the -- and I'll let Jeff talk kind of about the market and how we might grow into the market a little bit and focus on '17 pre-infrastructure build-out. But when we look at the exit at 2 Bcf, again, we're measuring our growth at this point in time. We have cash on the balance sheet. We have the ability to ramp-up as you might suspect. But we think prior to, again, getting closer to the in-service of the infrastructure, we think it is a benefit to keep this in-basin dynamic of restricted growth on the 3 pipes and the supply side in somewhat of a balance. But we do see it relatively -- and our plan is to stay relatively flat from an exit volume of 2 Bcf, and that's what got to my measured growth comment in '17 of 5% to 10%. Jeff, do you want to make any comments about kind of the dynamics of the market up there right now?

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. David, if you recall, we've been to 2 Bcf before. 2 Bcf a day is not a stretch in terms of moving gas and finding capacity and expanding our existing markets and our customer basis. Right now, and we talked a little bit about this on the first
componenttext: Yes, sure. David, if you recall, we've been to 2 Bcf before. 2 Bcf a day is not a stretch in terms of moving gas and finding capacity and expanding our existing markets and our customer basis. Right now, and we talked a little bit about this on the first call about the availability of excess firm capacity in the marketplace in the secondary market, we look at that every day. We're pretty happy we didn't pull the trigger back in February on a number of these capacity deals. The -- quite frankly, the rates keep improving. The options keep getting better. The volumes are more to our liking. The durations are more to our liking. And so we're watching this capacity release market very closely. And as we get further into the year, we find that there's more producers -- or I should call them producers/shippers that aren't using their capacity. And it's quite dynamic, but it's something that we think, at some point, we will pick up some additional capacity that just bridges the cap -- excuse me, bridges the gap over to -- closer to 2018. So a lot of options right now, and I think the -- there are really good options to improve netbacks.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I appreciate that color, Jeff. So it sounds like there is some potential, I guess, to see some release capacity in '17 then?
componenttext: I appreciate that color, Jeff. So it sounds like there is some potential, I guess, to see some release capacity in '17 then?

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016

componenttext: Potentially, yes.

componenttext: Just the last one that I had for you guys. How are you thinking about hedging right now? We've seen a lot of your peers that now hedges sort of in this $3 range in '17. And you guys kind of set put on that right now. How are you guys thinking about the hedge book going into next year?

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Our desire is to underpin some of our volumes with the hedge. We continue to look at the market and, again, trying to get a feel for a forward curve. We think that the opportunity to place hedges in the range that have been in the recent past, we thi
componenttext: Yes. Our desire is to underpin some of our volumes with the hedge. We continue to look at the market and, again, trying to get a feel for a forward curve. We think that the opportunity to place hedges in the range that have been in the recent past, we think that opportunity still exists out in front of us. And we think, actually, the opportunity could maybe improve from where some of the hedges have been placed behind us.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. So it sounds like you'd probably wait until, like, wintertime, I guess, before layering in something more?
componenttext: Got it. So it sounds like you'd probably wait until, like, wintertime, I guess, before layering in something more?

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We'll be opportunistic. I can't -- the market, as you know and we all know, is very dynamic and hard to predict with accuracy. But at least, it is our consensus with our Hedge Committee that we can still protect our volumes into '17 between now and t
componenttext: Yes. We'll be opportunistic. I can't -- the market, as you know and we all know, is very dynamic and hard to predict with accuracy. But at least, it is our consensus with our Hedge Committee that we can still protect our volumes into '17 between now and the end of the year.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Holly Stewart of Scotia Howard Weil.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Holly Stewart of Scotia Howard Weil.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just, Dan, you outlined in your prepared remarks just a lot of the projects that are coming online over the next couple of years to increase your capacity and, ultimately, your pricing. I think, Jeff, if you could just maybe help us better understand thes
componenttext: Just, Dan, you outlined in your prepared remarks just a lot of the projects that are coming online over the next couple of years to increase your capacity and, ultimately, your pricing. I think, Jeff, if you could just maybe help us better understand these power agreements. I think it's close to or over $400 million a day. Just trying to get a sense of maybe how we should model it. You mentioned, I think, within one of the releases that your gas price is directly linked to lower prices. So is that just based on the market heat rate? And then maybe which power prices had these issues with? I'm assuming PJM.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I'll turn it over to Jeff to give color, but -- and he knows, and I'm sure he'll reiterate the confidentiality of it. But he should be able to help give some better scoping of the power pricing.
componenttext: And I'll turn it over to Jeff to give color, but -- and he knows, and I'm sure he'll reiterate the confidentiality of it. But he should be able to help give some better scoping of the power pricing.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Holly, this is, of course, a sensitive subject. And we have -- we're -- first of all, we're very, very happy to be with our partners in the power generation business. Diversifying our commodity a little bit more to power from gas, and being in the l
componenttext: Okay. Holly, this is, of course, a sensitive subject. And we have -- we're -- first of all, we're very, very happy to be with our partners in the power generation business. Diversifying our commodity a little bit more to power from gas, and being in the local PJM area, as you mentioned, it's our benefit to link some power pricing to our gas prices. So the benefit of these 2 particular projects are unique in that, as Dan mentioned in the speech, that we -- literally, no FT that we had to buy to get there. So we're all of a sudden, out of the gate, we're $0.50 to $0.60 better than having to purchase long-term liability FT to get to these power plants. That said, the pricing for the power plants -- a small portion of each one of these plants is local pricing because power plants, generally, just buy gas, daily gas. So a small percentage of that load is related to local gas, daily pricing. However, what we've done is set arbitrary floors and caps under the agreement that protect Cabot and also protect the power generator, and we fluctuate between those floors and caps based on day forward power prices or at least a percent of day forward power price. And that enables, essentially, the generator and for Cabot to win. And it's just a -- that's a great structure for everyone.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So is there, like, a minimum volume? If the plant doesn't dispatch, do you still get paid?
componenttext: Okay. So is there, like, a minimum volume? If the plant doesn't dispatch, do you still get paid?

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Keep in mind, these are brand-new, high-efficiency plants. Their run time in the first 5 years will be at least 95% to 96%. So you have a couple of days of maintenance each year. Recall, too, that we have a fuel manager between us and the power generator.
componenttext: Keep in mind, these are brand-new, high-efficiency plants. Their run time in the first 5 years will be at least 95% to 96%. So you have a couple of days of maintenance each year. Recall, too, that we have a fuel manager between us and the power generator. And that fuel manager's role is to continue to purchase gas and move gas during days or an hour or whatever the case may be that the plant may not be operating. But we would fully expect these plants to operate at a very, very high load rate, at least, through the first 5 to 7 years.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016

componenttextpreview: And Holly, this is Jeff. One more thought on that. These projects sometimes tend to get out of control. In other words, when the maintenance is done, sometimes, it extends longer than those [indiscernible]. But in this case, the majority of the maintenanc
componenttext: And Holly, this is Jeff. One more thought on that. These projects sometimes tend to get out of control. In other words, when the maintenance is done, sometimes, it extends longer than those [indiscernible]. But in this case, the majority of the maintenance that we're experiencing, on Transco in particular, is quite frankly just pipe replacement. We're almost through it. In fact, it ends on July 30.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Charles Meade of Johnson Rice.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Charles Meade of Johnson Rice.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd like to explore a little bit more the -- your opportunities to be -- or your intent to be opportunistic in 1Q '17 and how that interacts with your decision to accelerate your completion base here in the back half of the year. Is this the sort of thing
componenttext: I'd like to explore a little bit more the -- your opportunities to be -- or your intent to be opportunistic in 1Q '17 and how that interacts with your decision to accelerate your completion base here in the back half of the year. Is this the sort of thing where you're committing to delivering more volumes in 1Q '17, anticipating some better realizations there? Or is this more about you building the optionality to perhaps capture just a week's worth of high local pricing in the event of a cold winter?

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We're not really doing for just a short-term grab, Charles. If you look at our plan that we're going to present in October to our board and you look at -- I obviously have the benefit of looking out a little late with the draft we have currently, and
componenttext: Yes. We're not really doing for just a short-term grab, Charles. If you look at our plan that we're going to present in October to our board and you look at -- I obviously have the benefit of looking out a little late with the draft we have currently, and if you look at that build that we have out in front of us and you go back to the infrastructure projects that we've highlighted here, and there's other things that Jeff is working on, we have to start at some point in time to plan, schedule in a efficient way, in the most efficient way, getting out ahead of a ramp of almost 2 Bcf a day additional production. And if you think about that, you say real quick, it's not that difficult. I have Phil Stalnaker sitting over here beside me, and he squirms every day when we look out at the end of '18, which is not that far out in front of us. And it's his group that is less than 100 people out there and -- but with some excellent rock, his job is to manage the economic growth of our operation out there and to build into this infrastructure. Now ideally, we were hoping what happen is Constitution would have come on by now, and as everybody knows the pains of that process. But we've stacked these other infrastructure projects in line now. But the good news is they're all going to happen, but they're going to happen kind of on top of each other and contemporaneous, which does require us to start out ahead of that ramp-up in a way that would have some of the decisions we're making today in preparation for what we expect to be able to build into as these projects come online. So we like the dynamics of where the market is, and we certainly like the better pricing we see. For example, to your point, in the first quarter of '17, that's all good. And certainly, we'll be in that space to benefit from it, but we were looking at more of a long-term build and getting up to the 3.5, 4 Bcf production range towards the end of '18.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful incremental detail. And if I could pick up on one of the things you talked about with this, you're really a much stronger roster of options on takeaway and demand scenario. My read is that, really, the big one, both in terms of volume and t
componenttext: That's helpful incremental detail. And if I could pick up on one of the things you talked about with this, you're really a much stronger roster of options on takeaway and demand scenario. My read is that, really, the big one, both in terms of volume and time line, really Atlantic Sunrise. But I'm wondering if you'd agree with that, and if you can kind of rank or maybe you put on a discussion in terms of both time line and volume which of the other of these projects, whether it's the Tennessee gas or the PennEast line, that would be #2 behind the Atlantic Sunrise in terms of the points?

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think it's -- quick comment, we had 850 million (sic) [850,000] a day on Atlantic Sunrise. That is the largest project that we have in the pool. And again, without Constitution and these other projects, we can get to the 3.5 plus or minus capacity
componenttext: Yes, I think it's -- quick comment, we had 850 million (sic) [850,000] a day on Atlantic Sunrise. That is the largest project that we have in the pool. And again, without Constitution and these other projects, we can get to the 3.5 plus or minus capacity without Constitution, and so that's all positive. And I'll let Jeff talk about the lineup, but each of these projects get different price points for us and should be an enhancement to our realizations. [indiscernible], Jeff?

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Charles, thanks for the question, by the way. The Atlantic Sunrise project is a big project in anyone's eyes. The scope is large, and the good news there is 850,000 a day of new capacity with a brand-new pipe coming into our backyard, but also 100%
componenttext: Okay. Charles, thanks for the question, by the way. The Atlantic Sunrise project is a big project in anyone's eyes. The scope is large, and the good news there is 850,000 a day of new capacity with a brand-new pipe coming into our backyard, but also 100% on the 850,000 a day of gas is sold and sold to 2 very good markets in -- to Cove Point LNG with Sumitomo, and of course  Washington Gas Light in the D.C. area. So absolutely, that's a standout project for us. As we move down the list, it's interesting that the next 4 projects that we have, and in total, these all add up to about 1.5 Bcf a day. Just make one comment, the good news is, on the 1.5, all the 50,000 a day is already placed and sold to very good markets. So in terms of ranking or just how excited we are about these projects over the next 18 months, both power plant facilities are way up there on the list: good markets, no transport, ratable burns. I mean, it's very exciting. The TGP Orion project of 135,000 a day, again, 100% of that gas is sold. And it's going to South Jersey to a power plant that they're going to operate in the southern part of New Jersey. Great pricing there. And then the PennEast Pipeline, that pipeline is 1 Bcf a day, and we have 100,000 sold already and 50,000 of capacity. But keep in mind, the impact of a PennEast or the impact of Atlantic Sunrise, what that's going to do to basis differentials on Transco? As you start moving, a lot of gas off that pipe, a lot of gas out of our supplier, where our expectations are that pricing raises differentials both on Tennessee and on Transco are going to improve. I mean, there's just -- there is no doubt in my mind. So not only do we have all these projects take away to the region, and you know a rising tide lifts all ships. And in this case, we expect to upgrade to local pricing on -- connected to all these projects.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dan, you talked to your lateral lengths of drilled wells rising to 7,000 feet and then a record well, I believe, at about 10,000 feet. Can you talk to how you see your average lateral lengths trending as we go into 2017? And as well, give us an update on
componenttext: Dan, you talked to your lateral lengths of drilled wells rising to 7,000 feet and then a record well, I believe, at about 10,000 feet. Can you talk to how you see your average lateral lengths trending as we go into 2017? And as well, give us an update on any changes impacting productivity from wells adjusted for lateral lengths.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, we have been able to continue to finish our laterals out. In '17, we expect our lateral lengths to continue to expand out beyond the 7,000 feet, so that's an ongoing project out there in Phil's area. And certainly, objective of ours to continue
componenttext: Yes. Well, we have been able to continue to finish our laterals out. In '17, we expect our lateral lengths to continue to expand out beyond the 7,000 feet, so that's an ongoing project out there in Phil's area. And certainly, objective of ours to continue to lengthen the laterals. The productivity is, as you might suspect, is in the -- several that we have in this range, we do see very good productivity. And it's simply a function of more stages in the lateral lengths, just staying fairly consistent with the average that we see per stage.

componenttext: Yes, yes.

componenttext: Well, the one comment I would make, first is when you're modeling, keep in mind, one of the biggest components of the power plants is going to be the -- don't put any firm transportation in the mix. We just don't have any of that. So that's going to be a firm input into your model.

componenttext: Just now on the last question, you had mentioned that CapEx might be 50% to 60% higher to -- relative to this year's guidance to meet that 5% to 10% growth rate for next year. componenttext: Yes. We have -- again, the ramp-up into that infrastructure will start with our '17 capital program. And again, a swag number, and it's anywhere from the $650 million to $675 million for '17, as kind of a swag number. And then as we go into '18, I do plan on putting out a little bit more forward-looking statement in either October or November of what we see building into that infrastructure build-out. I probably would not get granular with numbers on capital at all in '18 at that time, but I do plan on, and we will have discussion on, how much of a look do we want to give, what we look and our comfort level of our 5-year plan. And with that, I think that would give the market a great deal of comfort on what Cabot is going to be able to do to deliver value. And some of this, as -- what you do need to keep in mind, something different than where we are in '16, we kind of stripped out of '16 our investment capital pipeline, investment capital out of '16. And we have, in that number I'm giving you out there, as a swag of $650 million to $675 million. headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: You noted in your most recent presentation that you added 15% more locations with recent spacing test. I was just wondering, is this effort more or less complete? Or are you still testing downspacing in the Marcellus?
componenttext: You noted in your most recent presentation that you added 15% more locations with recent spacing test. I was just wondering, is this effort more or less complete? Or are you still testing downspacing in the Marcellus?

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We will continue to test not only how tight we can get locations, and Phil has a couple downspace opportunities or wells that we look at. But we'll also continue to explore with stage loading and spaces, spacing between clusters as part of our effort
componenttext: Yes. We will continue to test not only how tight we can get locations, and Phil has a couple downspace opportunities or wells that we look at. But we'll also continue to explore with stage loading and spaces, spacing between clusters as part of our efforts to see how we can enhance the program. One of the July period for Cabot at our board meetings is opportunity for our geologist to stand before the board and talk about our exploration projects, ideas that we have, and we do have some, and we did present several to our board on Wednesday. But one of the things also the technical group has done in the North has -- is taking a step back. We have a huge database, as you can surmise, and look at the entire space and determine what we might do different with a blank piece of paper, starting over to try to look at all the different aspects, all the way from planning areas, steering, penetration rates, how we initiate fracs, how we bring back the wells. All of that is being scrutinized in a project-orientated fashion that I imagine Phil would come back and discuss at a later date. Phil, do you want to make any sentimental [indiscernible]?

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. Again, our guys are doing a great job. And kind of like Dan said, we're in every aspect of it, so stage spacing, clusters, a number of clusters, landing points, challenges breaking down each component of the reservoir. So again, it's an ongoing effort
componenttext: No. Again, our guys are doing a great job. And kind of like Dan said, we're in every aspect of it, so stage spacing, clusters, a number of clusters, landing points, challenges breaking down each component of the reservoir. So again, it's an ongoing effort here to continue to optimize our potential out there.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016

componenttext: And one of the things also is not only looking at the upper Marcellus and all the way through [indiscernible] our Marcellus. But the complexity of the geology, looking at the relationship to production profiles within some of the proximity to some of the larger faulting systems and also looking at a couple of different zones in the section that we think hold for what I would catch today as exploratory promise.

componenttext: Oh, okay. Great. If I can finish with a kind of a little devil's advocate question, but it also relates to something that Jeff was talking about earlier about the -- potentially growing availability of capacity on existing infrastructure. To what extent do you think you could protect your [indiscernible] Atlantic Sunrise volumes if that project is delayed? Meaning, can you scramble around on some of the existing infrastructure and the freeing-up capacity to help you if there's some kind of environmental pushback on that and gets delayed by 6 months or 9 months or whatever?

componenttext: Yes. So we have -- let me back up. We watch this very closely, of course, and we are very comfortable where we stand and with the permitting process and the regulatory process. So we're content that the project is moving forward and excited that it's moving forward and has an in-service opportunity late 2017. That said, we do have plan B and plan C and plan D to move volumes in different directions and to different places to -- or should I say just in case that the project is delayed a month or 3 months or something to that extent. So we probably wouldn't be able to find a home day 1 for 850,000 a day to premium markets, but we would be able to adjust to that based on the deadline that we would see if it wasn't delayed.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right, Ericson. I don't have any additional remarks. But just to reemphasize that we are extremely pleased with the operational side of our program. We are building into the infrastructure build-out, starting the early stages of some excitement about
componenttext:
All right, Ericson. I don't have any additional remarks. But just to reemphasize that we are extremely pleased with the operational side of our program. We are building into the infrastructure build-out, starting the early stages of some excitement about seeing some tangible results in that area. And I think it's going to be fun for our operating group to now diligently start being able to use their talents, secure the services and equipment and start a very diligent process in building these significant volumes. 
If you look out there in the space, I don't know if any other company that has an opportunity and the rock to be able -- and the balance sheet to be able to grow production, double production in the next couple of years and have the benefits to -- and shareholders as Cabot does. 
So thank you for your interest, and we are excited about presenting our 5-year plan to our board in October. And we do anticipate offering maybe a little bit more color either on October or February, we haven't made that call, of a little bit longer outlook for what Cabot has to offer. 
So thanks again, and look forward to the next quarterly call.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, and welcome to the Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation's Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call and Webcast. [Operator Instructions] Please note, this event is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to Mr. Dan Dinges, Chair
componenttext:
Good day, and welcome to the Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation's Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call and Webcast. [Operator Instructions] Please note, this event is being recorded. 
I would now like to turn the conference over to Mr. Dan Dinges, Chairman, President and CEO. Please go ahead.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Ericson, and thank you all for joining this morning for Cabot's Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. I have today with me several members of the executive team. Before we start, let me do say that the standard boilerplate regarding forward-look
componenttext:
Thank you, Ericson, and thank you all for joining this morning for Cabot's Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. I have today with me several members of the executive team. 
Before we start, let me do say that the standard boilerplate regarding forward-looking statements included in this morning's press release applies to my comments on today's call. 
Cabot's second quarter results highlight our ability to deliver production growth while also generating positive free cash flow even in a low commodity price environment. We believe this characteristic sets us apart for most of our industry peers. 
Cabot averaged 1.67 Bcfe per day of net production during the quarter, an increase of 10% compared to the second quarter of 2015. This increase was driven by 14% increase in our Marcellus production volumes as compared to the prior year comparable quarter. Despite a realized natural gas price of only $1.63 per Mcf, we generated positive free cash flow for the quarter, and we anticipate that the company will be able to deliver a more meaningful level of free cash flow during the second half of the year based on current strip prices.
Natural gas realizations did improve by 9% sequentially as compared to the first quarter of the year, due in part to a significant improvement in local basis differential during the quarter. Before the impact of derivatives, Cabot's realizations were $0.40 below the average NYMEX settle price of $1.95 during the quarter as compared to $0.60 below the average NYMEX settlement price in the first quarter. While basis differentials have subsequently widened in the third quarter due to a significant increase in the NYMEX prices, the good news is that we are forecasting much higher price realizations during the second half of the year, resulting in more free cash flow for the year than originally forecast. This increase in expected cash flows has allowed for the introduction of a second frac crew in the Marcellus for a portion of the second half of the year, which will help give us a jump start on 2017 production. 
Using the current 5-year forward curve for Leidy Line, which is a good proxy for the most punitive pricing a portion of our Marcellus production receives, our well level internal rate of returns are over 100%, and our PV-10s are approximately $14 million. I cannot think of another asset that generates those economics in the current price environment, and therefore, we feel extremely comfortable about slightly increasing our levels of operating activity beginning with this additional frac crew. 
The second quarter results also demonstrate our continued emphasis on cost control, with unit costs declining by 12% compared to the prior year comparable quarter and 2% compared to the first quarter of this year. We have now delivered a sequential decline in unit costs for 12 of the last 13 quarters and expect this trend to continue, further improving our industry-leading cost structure. 
Our balance sheet remains extremely strong, with over $500 million of cash on hand and a net debt to EBITDAX ratio of only 1.8x at quarter-end. Based on our current forecast, we anticipate delevering between now and year-end, while our current liquidity of $2.2 billion should continue to improve given our outlook for positive free cash flow in the second half of the year. This financial flexibility will serve us well as we formulate our plans for 2017 and beyond. 
In the Marcellus, we continue to operate one drilling rig, and as mentioned, have recently added a second frac crew to accelerate the completion of our DUC inventory, which will allow for an acceleration of production in the first quarter of 2017. 
During the quarter, we drilled 7 wells, completed 8 wells, and placed 12 wells on production. The average lateral length for the 7 wells drilled during the second quarter was approximately 7,000 feet. However, given that all of the wells, 100% of the wells we placed on production year-to-date, were drilled in '15, and the average lateral length was a little bit shorter and closer to 6,000 feet. The good news is that we should continue improvements in capital efficiency in 2017 as we've began placing all production on the longer lateral wells from this year program. 
On the production front, we averaged approximately 1.54 Bcf per day of net production for the Marcellus during the quarter, which was slightly below the midpoint of our expectations due to unscheduled downtime related to infrastructure maintenance in the region. Had we not experienced this downtime, we would have eclipsed the high end of our production guidance range for the quarter. Unfortunately, July production volumes have also been impacted somewhat by outages on Transco for the majority of the month. However, we are confident that we'll be able to keep production levels flat for the second quarter based on our plans on placing 12 wells on production during the third quarter. 
On the operations front, our drilling team continues to capture more efficiency gains, which was evident by new record for drilling days during the quarter of approximately 9 days for spud to TD and 13 days for spud to spud. We also drilled our longest Marcellus well to date with a total measured depth of over 18,000 feet and a lateral length of over 10,000 feet, which is scheduled to be completed in 2017.
A brief comment on our Eagle Ford shale. Despite a significant reduction in our Eagle Ford operating activity, including no wells drilled and only 3 wells completed during the quarter, our oil volumes for the second quarter exceeded our guidance due to outperformance from the newer wells that were placed on production. Given that our last Eagle Ford well was placed on production in May, we are not placing any wells on production during the third quarter. We are forecasting declines in our oil production volumes for the remainder of the year, which is in line with our original plan. At this point in time, based on our current outlook on oil prices, our plan is to continue to allocate a minimal amount of capital to our Eagle Ford assets, and instead, focus on arresting base declines, meeting our leasehold obligations and waiting for a slightly higher oil price environment before allocating any additional capital to this asset. 
I would highlight that even in today's prices, our returns in Eagle Ford far exceed our cost of capital. But given the much higher returns we see in the Marcellus, we believe the best place for additional capital today is in Susquehanna County. 
As you may all be aware, Cabot is directly involved with multiple pipeline ventures that focus on our growth opportunities over the next several years. I would like to provide a few updates and comments on the progress of these important infrastructure projects since our last call. 
Regarding Constitution, our initial appellant brief was filed on July 12, 2016 with the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, including -- included in this brief is a very comprehensive summary of the issues we found regarding the New York DEC water quality application process, and additionally outlines the schedule for the appeal process. Together, this brief should answer the majority of your questions concerning Constitution. 
We have made progress as well with Atlantic Sunrise during early March. The FERC issued a scheduling notice for Atlantic Sunrise, and on May 5, 2016, issued the draft environmental impact statement. Our expectations are to receive the final environmental impact statement during October, and to remain on schedule for a late 2017 in-service. 
For the Tennessee gas pipeline Orion project, the FERC also issued their scheduling notice for environmental review during June and indicated that the final environmental assessment would be issued by mid August, 2016. This $135 million per day project remains on schedule for a June 18 in-service date. 
Also of note was the recent issuance of the draft environmental impact statement by the FERC on the 1 Bcf a day PennEast project. The final EIS is scheduled for mid-December, and this project remains on schedule for late '18. As a reminder, Cabot has $150 million a day committed to the PennEast project. 
Moving on to our recent announcements of Lackawanna Energy Center power facility. We are very excited to be the exclusive provider of up to 240 million cubic foot a day to Pennsylvania's largest natural gas facility and one of the most efficient power plants in the U.S. Together with our previous announcement to provide 100% of the natural gas requirements to the Moxie Freedom plan, Cabot will be providing more than 400 million cubic foot a day to local demand projects. Both facilities are essentially tied into our gathering system, eliminating the need to commit to expensive long-term FT agreements. 
And our pricing terms, although confidential, provide very attractive rates of returns with netbacks that are expected to be materially better than our anticipated netbacks in the local region. Assuming a gross exit rate for this year of approximately 2 Bcf per day, we have line of sight to double our production to over 4 Bcf per day, assuming all of the announced projects are approved and built. 
For all the Constitution naysayers out there, while we're still extremely confident that the project is ultimately constructed even without Constitution volumes, we still have direct line of sight to have the ability to produce over 3.5 Bcf per day by the end of 2018, which is effectively double the production levels we average during the second quarter. Not to mention, our marketing team continues to evaluate additional projects that would all be incremental to the numbers I just discussed.
And our outlook comment. As a result of continued efficiency gains and incremental cost savings, the company plans to complete an additional 15 to 20 Marcellus wells during the second half of the year and will also incur an additional $20 million of capital. The production impact of accelerated Marcellus completions will not be realized until early 2017, therefore, we're leaving our current '16 production guidance unchanged. 
While our plan for '17 are still being evaluated and our official budget will not be announced until October, I can say that measured growth in the 5% to 10% range in '17 is a prudent and reasonable assumption. And based on today's outlook, we would generate even more positive free cash flow next year than we will this year. 
When you look at Cabot's story over the next several years, I see a company with a strong balance sheet that continues to get better, best-in-class economics that continue to improve, cash margins that are expected to almost double by 2018 at this current strip, a growth outlook that allows for a doubling of Marcellus production volumes once the majority of our infrastructure is in service and a significant level of free cash flow accumulated during the period of time, providing optionality for program acceleration, dividend enhancement, share buyback, balance sheet management, et cetera. 
Needless to say, the outlook for Cabot is certainly bright, and I look forward to providing more details about our long-term plans in October. 
Ericson, with that brief statement, I'll be more than happy to answer any questions.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
