headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Okay, Neal. The differentials in the second quarter certainly improved, and a lot of that was related to the drop in NYMEX. We saw Henry Hub in the second quarter averaged about $0.95. And compared to the second quarter of '15, for example, it was $2
componenttext: Yes. Okay, Neal. The differentials in the second quarter certainly improved, and a lot of that was related to the drop in NYMEX. We saw Henry Hub in the second quarter averaged about $0.95. And compared to the second quarter of '15, for example, it was $2.64, and we saw about half the differential this year compared to last year. And of course, we had the rally during June on NYMEX going forward for the rest of the year, so our diffs definitely widened out a little bit. But we're going to see that volatility all year long as we watch these storage injection numbers and watch the market tighten.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Drew Venker of Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Drew Venker of Morgan Stanley.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was hoping you can talk about what you're seeing in terms of acquisition opportunities. You have significant free cash flow generation which I think is rare nowadays amongst your peers, so, just would like to hear your thinking about that.
componenttext: I was hoping you can talk about what you're seeing in terms of acquisition opportunities. You have significant free cash flow generation which I think is rare nowadays amongst your peers, so, just would like to hear your thinking about that.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Drew, a good question. We get that M&A question because we do have such a strong balance sheet and great cash flow. We look at deals out there. We look at opportunities, and we try to stack them against what we have as our ongoing model. We put toget
componenttext: Yes, Drew, a good question. We get that M&A question because we do have such a strong balance sheet and great cash flow. We look at deals out there. We look at opportunities, and we try to stack them against what we have as our ongoing model. We put together -- or I should say -- are in the process of putting together a 5-year model. We'll present this 5-year plan to our board in October. In discussions with that model, when you look at our organic program, what we are able to achieve with the assumptions that we placed in there on commodity pricing. And then we also look at the available opportunities out there and also just our own internal ideas of what we might be able to do different to enhance long-term shareholder value. And that's a continuing discussion we have in our board meeting, not only in every board meeting, but we also have an off-site meeting, many are aware, in September. That is a strategic discussion at the 30,000-foot level, the macro market, the movements in the market, strengths of the market, opportunities in the market to see how we can continue to enhance shareholder value. So we have not been an acquisitive company, but we have been a company that continues to evaluate the opportunities that are out there and the asset basis and/or, in some cases, the corporate companies that have possible needs and their future to do something different. So we haven't made any decisions, but we do evaluate the market.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dan, just to follow-up on that, I guess the -- part of what I'm curious about is with the rates return you can generate in the Marcellus, whether you really see much that's competitive with that on an acquisition front or if that's how you think about it.
componenttext: Dan, just to follow-up on that, I guess the -- part of what I'm curious about is with the rates return you can generate in the Marcellus, whether you really see much that's competitive with that on an acquisition front or if that's how you think about it. And as you've gone through the deal process, has there been anything that's come close to meeting those thresholds that you need to move forward with an acquisition?

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We have, I think, demonstrated with our plan, how we're running the company and what we have done and trying to rationalize our growth and measured growth is what we have provided. We do that because we are trying to maximize our return in a soft com
componenttext: Yes. We have, I think, demonstrated with our plan, how we're running the company and what we have done and trying to rationalize our growth and measured growth is what we have provided. We do that because we are trying to maximize our return in a soft commodity price environment, and we're certainly trying to look at the market in a macro sense to determine what we think best -- our input into the market and how we think that would best maintain the margins and strength of Cabot. So when you look at the M&A market, diversity is one of those areas that we discuss, not only geographic diversity, but also commodity diversity. We look at that in a way that compares what we have in our organic program, the risk of execution of our organic program and how we might be able to enhance the valuations, the return profile in our program if, in fact, we had a bolt-on, we had a new greenfield operation or we had a merge opportunity out there. And to your point, what we receive on a term profile with every dollar that Cabot invests, it does challenge us to look at the market out there, to look at other assets and to be able to say that we are prepared to displace any capital allocated to our Marcellus and allocate elsewhere. And when we don't get comfortable with that, in essence, dilution of that investment in that context, we do look at the infrastructure build-out, we know we have a significant growth profile coming for Cabot, and it's just around the corner. It's now not measured really in years. It's measured in months of when we're going to see that. So our focus is more internally, right now, to get our program lined up and to be prepared to grow into that market, double our production or greater and do that as efficiently as we can.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from David Deckelbaum of KeyBanc.
componenttext: Our next question comes from David Deckelbaum of KeyBanc.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dan, can you give any color -- I guess, you talked about exiting this year, I think, at 2 Bcf a day gross, and I guess you'd be ramping onto that first quarter there. Is the thought, I guess, you'd be basically at your capacity almost in 1Q in terms of de
componenttext: Dan, can you give any color -- I guess, you talked about exiting this year, I think, at 2 Bcf a day gross, and I guess you'd be ramping onto that first quarter there. Is the thought, I guess, you'd be basically at your capacity almost in 1Q in terms of deliverability, and you'd more or less hold that number kind of flattish throughout the rest of '17 unless there is some other release capacity out there?

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We think that the -- and I'll let Jeff talk kind of about the market and how we might grow into the market a little bit and focus on '17 pre-infrastructure build-out. But when we look at the exit at 2 Bcf, again, we're measuring our growth at this po
componenttext: Yes. We think that the -- and I'll let Jeff talk kind of about the market and how we might grow into the market a little bit and focus on '17 pre-infrastructure build-out. But when we look at the exit at 2 Bcf, again, we're measuring our growth at this point in time. We have cash on the balance sheet. We have the ability to ramp-up as you might suspect. But we think prior to, again, getting closer to the in-service of the infrastructure, we think it is of benefit to keep this in-basin dynamic of restricted growth on the 3 pipes and the supply side in somewhat of a balance. But we do see it relatively -- and our plan is to stay relatively flat from an exit volume of 2 Bcf, and that's what got to my measured growth comment in '17 of 5% to 10%. Jeff, do you want to make any comments about kind of the dynamics of the market up there right now?

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. David, if you recall, we've been to 2 Bcf before. 2 Bcf a day is not a stretch in terms of moving gas and finding capacity and expanding our existing markets and our customer basis. Right now, and we talked a little bit about this on the first
componenttext: Yes, sure. David, if you recall, we've been to 2 Bcf before. 2 Bcf a day is not a stretch in terms of moving gas and finding capacity and expanding our existing markets and our customer basis. Right now, and we talked a little bit about this on the first call about the availability of excess firm capacity in the marketplace in the secondary market. We look at that every day. We're pretty happy we didn't pull the trigger back in February on a number of these capacity deals. The -- quite frankly, the rates keep improving. The options keep getting better. The volumes are more to our liking. The durations are more to our liking. And so we're watching this capacity release market very closely. And as we get further into the year, we find that there's more producers -- or I should call them producers/shippers that aren't using their capacity. And it's quite dynamic, but it's something that we think, at some point, we will pick up some additional capacity that just bridges the cap -- excuse me, bridges the gap over to -- closer to 2018. So a lot of options right now, and I think the -- there are really good options to improve netbacks.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I appreciate that color, Jeff. So it sounds like there is some potential, I guess, to see some release capacity in '17 then?
componenttext: I appreciate that color, Jeff. So it sounds like there is some potential, I guess, to see some release capacity in '17 then?

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Potentially, yes.
componenttext: Potentially, yes.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just the last one that I had for you guys. How are you thinking about hedging right now? We've seen a lot of your peers that now hedges sort of in this $3 range in '17. And you guys kind of set put on that right now. How are you guys thinking about the he
componenttext: Just the last one that I had for you guys. How are you thinking about hedging right now? We've seen a lot of your peers that now hedges sort of in this $3 range in '17. And you guys kind of set put on that right now. How are you guys thinking about the hedge book going into next year?

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Our desire is to underpin some of our volumes with the hedge. We continue to look at the market and, again, trying to get a feel for a forward curve. We think that the opportunity to place hedges in the range that have been in the recent past, we thi
componenttext: Yes. Our desire is to underpin some of our volumes with the hedge. We continue to look at the market and, again, trying to get a feel for a forward curve. We think that the opportunity to place hedges in the range that have been in the recent past, we think that opportunity still exists out in front of us. And we think, actually, the opportunity could maybe improve from where some of the hedges have been placed behind us.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. So it sounds like you'd probably wait until, like, wintertime, I guess, before layering in something more?
componenttext: Got it. So it sounds like you'd probably wait until, like, wintertime, I guess, before layering in something more?

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We'll be opportunistic. I can't -- the market, as you know and we all know, is very dynamic and hard to predict with accuracy. But at least, it is our consensus with our Hedge Committee that we can still protect our volumes into '17 between now and t
componenttext: Yes. We'll be opportunistic. I can't -- the market, as you know and we all know, is very dynamic and hard to predict with accuracy. But at least, it is our consensus with our Hedge Committee that we can still protect our volumes into '17 between now and the end of the year.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Holly Stewart of Scotia Howard Weil.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Holly Stewart of Scotia Howard Weil.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just, Dan, you outlined in your prepared remarks just a lot of the projects that are coming online over the next couple of years to increase your capacity and, ultimately, your pricing. I think, Jeff, if you could just maybe help us better understand thes
componenttext: Just, Dan, you outlined in your prepared remarks just a lot of the projects that are coming online over the next couple of years to increase your capacity and, ultimately, your pricing. I think, Jeff, if you could just maybe help us better understand these power agreements. I think it's close to or over $400 million a day. Just trying to get a sense of maybe how we should model it. You mentioned, I think, within one of the releases that your gas price is directly linked to power prices. So is that just based on the market heat rate? And then maybe which power prices had these issues with? I'm assuming PJM.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I'll turn it over to Jeff to give color, but -- and he knows, and I'm sure he'll reiterate the confidentiality of it. But he should be able to help give some better scoping of the power pricing.
componenttext: And I'll turn it over to Jeff to give color, but -- and he knows, and I'm sure he'll reiterate the confidentiality of it. But he should be able to help give some better scoping of the power pricing.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Holly, this is, of course, a sensitive subject. And we have -- we're -- first of all, we're very, very happy to be with our partners in the power generation business. Diversifying our commodity a little bit more to power from gas, and being in the l
componenttext: Okay. Holly, this is, of course, a sensitive subject. And we have -- we're -- first of all, we're very, very happy to be with our partners in the power generation business. Diversifying our commodity a little bit more to power from gas, and being in the local PJM area, as you mentioned, it's our benefit to link some power pricing to our gas prices. So the benefit of these 2 particular projects are unique in that, as Dan mentioned in the speech, that we -- literally, no FT that we had to buy to get there. So we're all of a sudden, out of the gate, we're $0.50 to $0.60 better than having to purchase long-term liability FT to get to these power plants. That said, the pricing for the power plants -- a small portion of each one of these plants is local pricing because power plants, generally, just buy gas, daily gas. So a small percentage of that load is related to local gas, daily pricing. However, what we've done is set arbitrary floors and caps under the agreement that protect Cabot and also protect the power generator, and we fluctuate between those floors and caps based on day forward power prices or at least a percent of day forward power price. And that enables, essentially, the generator and for Cabot to win. And it's just a -- that's a great structure for everyone.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So is there, like, a minimum volume? If the plant doesn't dispatch, do you still get paid?
componenttext: Okay. So is there, like, a minimum volume? If the plant doesn't dispatch, do you still get paid?

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Keep in mind, these are brand-new, high-efficiency plants. Their run time in the first 5 years will be at least 95% to 96%. So you have a couple of days of maintenance each year. Recall, too, that we have a fuel manager between us and the power generator.
componenttext: Keep in mind, these are brand-new, high-efficiency plants. Their run time in the first 5 years will be at least 95% to 96%. So you have a couple of days of maintenance each year. Recall, too, that we have a fuel manager between us and the power generator. And that fuel manager's role is to continue to purchase gas and move gas during days or an hour or whatever the case may be that the plant may not be operating. But we would fully expect these plants to operate at a very, very high load rate, at least, through the first 5 to 7 years.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got you. Okay. Great. That's helpful. And then maybe just one on -- I know there's -- you mentioned the pipeline maintenance. There's a lot of maintenance going on during the third quarter. Have you anticipated any curtailment in your guidance for 3Q?
componenttext: Got you. Okay. Great. That's helpful. And then maybe just one on -- I know there's -- you mentioned the pipeline maintenance. There's a lot of maintenance going on during the third quarter. Have you anticipated any curtailment in your guidance for 3Q?

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let's see. There's a minimum curtailed volume. I don't have the exact amount of curtailed volume. There is -- as we typically do, Holly, we put a risk profile on our production volumes and the curtailed volume there also, and I don't have that number righ
componenttext: Let's see. There's a minimum curtailed volume. I don't have the exact amount of curtailed volume. There is -- as we typically do, Holly, we put a risk profile on our production volumes and the curtailed volume there also, and I don't have that number right in front of me. I'm sorry.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Holly, this is Jeff. One more thought on that. These projects sometimes tend to get out of control. In other words, when the maintenance is done, sometimes, it extends longer than the notice are scheduled for. But in this case, the majority of the mai
componenttext: And Holly, this is Jeff. One more thought on that. These projects sometimes tend to get out of control. In other words, when the maintenance is done, sometimes, it extends longer than the notice are scheduled for. But in this case, the majority of the maintenance that we're experiencing, on Transco in particular, is quite frankly just pipe replacement. We're almost through it. In fact, it ends on July 30.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Charles Meade of Johnson Rice.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Charles Meade of Johnson Rice.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd like to explore a little bit more the -- your opportunities to be -- or your intent to be opportunistic in 1Q '17 and how that interacts with your decision to accelerate your completion base here in the back half of the year. Is this the sort of thing
componenttext: I'd like to explore a little bit more the -- your opportunities to be -- or your intent to be opportunistic in 1Q '17 and how that interacts with your decision to accelerate your completion base here in the back half of the year. Is this the sort of thing where you're committing to delivering more volumes in 1Q '17, anticipating some better realizations there? Or is this more about you building the optionality to perhaps capture just a week's worth of high local pricing in the event of a cold winter?

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We're not really doing for just a short-term grab, Charles. If you look at our plan that we're going to present in October to our board and you look at -- I obviously have the benefit of looking out a little ways with the draft we have currently, and
componenttext: Yes. We're not really doing for just a short-term grab, Charles. If you look at our plan that we're going to present in October to our board and you look at -- I obviously have the benefit of looking out a little ways with the draft we have currently, and if you look at that build that we have out in front of us and you go back to the infrastructure projects that we've highlighted here, and there's other things that Jeff is working on, we have to start at some point in time to plan, schedule in a efficient way, in the most efficient way, getting out ahead of a ramp of almost 2 Bcf a day additional production. And if you think about that, you say real quick, it's not that difficult. I have Phil Stalnaker sitting over here beside me, and he squirms every day when we look out at the end of '18, which is not that far out in front of us. And it's his group that is less than 100 people out there and -- but with some excellent rock, his job is to manage the economic growth of our operation out there and to build into this infrastructure. Now ideally, we were hoping what happen is Constitution would have come on by now, and as everybody knows the pains of that process. But we've stacked these other infrastructure projects in line now. But the good news is they're all going to happen, but they're going to happen kind of on top of each other and contemporaneous, which does require us to start out ahead of that ramp-up in a way that would have some of the decisions we're making today in preparation for what we expect to be able to build into as these projects come online. So we like the dynamics of where the market is, and we certainly like the better pricing we see. For example, to your point, in the first quarter of '17, that's all good. And certainly, we'll be in that space to benefit from it, but we were looking at more of a long-term build and getting up to the 3.5, 4 Bcf production range towards the end of '18.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful incremental detail. And if I could pick up on one of the things you talked about with this, you're really a much stronger roster of options on takeaway and demand scenario. My read is that, really, the big one, both in terms of volume and t
componenttext: That's helpful incremental detail. And if I could pick up on one of the things you talked about with this, you're really a much stronger roster of options on takeaway and demand scenario. My read is that, really, the big one, both in terms of volume and time line, really Atlantic Sunrise. But I'm wondering if you'd agree with that, and if you can kind of rank or maybe you put on a discussion in terms of both time line and volume which of the other of these projects, whether it's the Tennessee gas or the PennEast line, that would be #2 behind the Atlantic Sunrise in terms of the points?

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think it's -- quick comment, we had 850 million (sic) [850,000] a day on Atlantic Sunrise. That is the largest project that we have in the pool. And again, without Constitution and these other projects, we can get to the 3.5 plus or minus capacity
componenttext: Yes, I think it's -- quick comment, we had 850 million (sic) [850,000] a day on Atlantic Sunrise. That is the largest project that we have in the pool. And again, without Constitution and these other projects, we can get to the 3.5 plus or minus capacity without Constitution, and so that's all positive. And I'll let Jeff talk about the lineup, but each of these projects get different price points for us and should be an enhancement to our realizations. [indiscernible], Jeff?

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Charles, thanks for the question, by the way. The Atlantic Sunrise project is a big project in anyone's eyes. The scope is large, and the good news there is 850,000 a day of new capacity with a brand-new pipe coming into our backyard, but also 100%
componenttext: Okay. Charles, thanks for the question, by the way. The Atlantic Sunrise project is a big project in anyone's eyes. The scope is large, and the good news there is 850,000 a day of new capacity with a brand-new pipe coming into our backyard, but also 100% on the 850,000 a day of gas is sold and sold to 2 very good markets in -- to Cove Point LNG with Sumitomo, and of course Washington Gas Light in the D.C. area. So absolutely, that's a standout project for us. As we move down the list, it's interesting that the next 4 projects that we have, and in total, these all add up to about 1.5 Bcf a day. Just make one comment, the good news is, on the 1.5, all the 50,000 a day is already placed and sold to very good markets. So in terms of ranking or just how excited we are about these projects over the next 18 months, both power plant facilities are way up there on the list: good markets, no transport, ratable burns. I mean, it's very exciting. The TGP Orion project of 135,000 a day, again, 100% of that gas is sold. And it's going to South Jersey to a power plant that they're going to operate in the southern part of New Jersey. Great pricing there. And then the PennEast Pipeline, that pipeline is 1 Bcf a day, and we have 100,000 sold already and 50,000 of capacity. But keep in mind, the impact of a PennEast or the impact of Atlantic Sunrise, what that's going to do to basis differentials on Transco? As you start moving, a lot of gas off that pipe, a lot of gas out of our supplier, where our expectations are that pricing raises differentials both on Tennessee and on Transco are going to improve. I mean, there's just -- there is no doubt in my mind. So not only do we have all these projects take away to the region, and you know a rising tide lifts all ships. And in this case, we expect an upgrade to local pricing on -- connected to all these projects.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Brian Singer of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Brian Singer of Goldman Sachs.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dan, you talked to your lateral lengths of drilled wells rising to 7,000 feet and then a record well, I believe, at about 10,000 feet. Can you talk to how you see your average lateral lengths trending as we go into 2017? And as well, give us an update on
componenttext: Dan, you talked to your lateral lengths of drilled wells rising to 7,000 feet and then a record well, I believe, at about 10,000 feet. Can you talk to how you see your average lateral lengths trending as we go into 2017? And as well, give us an update on any changes impacting productivity from wells adjusted for lateral lengths.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, we have been able to continue to finish our laterals out. In '17, we expect our lateral lengths to continue to expand out beyond the 7,000 feet, so that's an ongoing project out there in Phil's area. And certainly, objective of ours to continue
componenttext: Yes. Well, we have been able to continue to finish our laterals out. In '17, we expect our lateral lengths to continue to expand out beyond the 7,000 feet, so that's an ongoing project out there in Phil's area. And certainly, objective of ours to continue to lengthen the laterals. The productivity is, as you might suspect, is in the -- several that we have in this range, we do see very good productivity. And it's simply a function of more stages in the lateral lengths, just staying fairly consistent with the average that we see per stage.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. So the increased well performance would be a function essentially of the higher lateral length. If we divide it by lateral length, we'll get to a similar type rate?
componenttext: Got it. So the increased well performance would be a function essentially of the higher lateral length. If we divide it by lateral length, we'll get to a similar type rate?

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, yes.
componenttext: Yes, yes.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then I wanted to follow up on Holly's question with regards to the power plants contracts. And maybe I'll try to characterize it this way, and I'm sure we can all model and come up with our estimates for the future. But to the degree that you ha
componenttext: Okay. And then I wanted to follow up on Holly's question with regards to the power plants contracts. And maybe I'll try to characterize it this way, and I'm sure we can all model and come up with our estimates for the future. But to the degree that you had all the incremental volumes from the local power plant contracts on now or in the second quarter, would that be accretive, dilutive or neutral to corporate -- or to your average gas price realization before hedging?

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the one comment I would make, first is when you're modeling, keep in mind, one of the biggest components of the power plants is going to be the -- don't put any firm transportation in the mix. We just don't have any of that. So that's going to be a
componenttext: Well, the one comment I would make, first is when you're modeling, keep in mind, one of the biggest components of the power plants is going to be the -- don't put any firm transportation in the mix. We just don't have any of that. So that's going to be a firm input into your model.

componenttext: Yes. The DUC count, we anticipate at year-end is approximately 15 wells in the Eagle Ford and 30 to 35 wells in Pennsylvania.

componenttextpreview: Not really. We've been -- we were forced to curtail by virtue of the unscheduled downtime. But it's our analysis -- including the volumes for Cabot, it's our analysis that the gas that can move up is moving, not only by us but our peers, and we think that
componenttext: Not really. We've been -- we were forced to curtail by virtue of the unscheduled downtime. But it's our analysis -- including the volumes for Cabot, it's our analysis that the gas that can move up is moving, not only by us but our peers, and we think that the day of the curtailed volumes is behind us.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Pearce Hammond of Simmons Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Pearce Hammond of Simmons Piper Jaffray.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just now on the last question, you had mentioned that CapEx might be 50% to 60% higher to -- relative to this year's guidance to meet that 5% to 10% growth rate for next year. Is that sort of the level of CapEx that you'd need to kind of get to that doubl
componenttext: Just now on the last question, you had mentioned that CapEx might be 50% to 60% higher to -- relative to this year's guidance to meet that 5% to 10% growth rate for next year. Is that sort of the level of CapEx that you'd need to kind of get to that double your production by the end of '18? Or would you need to build upon that?

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: We would have to build upon that, Pearce.
componenttext: We would have to build upon that, Pearce.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We have -- again, the ramp-up into that infrastructure will start with our '17 capital program. And again, a swag number, and it's anywhere from the $650 million to $675 million for '17, as kind of a swag number. And then as we go into '18, I do plan
componenttext: Yes. We have -- again, the ramp-up into that infrastructure will start with our '17 capital program. And again, a swag number, and it's anywhere from the $650 million to $675 million for '17, as kind of a swag number. And then as we go into '18, I do plan on putting out a little bit more forward-looking statement in either October or November of what we see building into that infrastructure build-out. I probably would not get granular with numbers on capital at all in '18 at that time, but I do plan on, and we will have discussion on, how much of a look do we want to give, what we look and our comfort level of our 5-year plan. And with that, I think that would give the market a great deal of comfort on what Cabot is going to be able to do to deliver value. And some of this, as -- what you do need to keep in mind, something different than where we are in '16, we kind of stripped out of '16 our investment capital pipeline, investment capital out of '16. And we have, in that number I'm giving you out there, as a swag of $650 million to $675 million. We have, in that number, plus or minus $125 million of that investment capital back in the '17 capital number so...

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: For the pipeline?

componenttext: You noted in your most recent presentation that you added 15% more locations with recent spacing test. I was just wondering, is this effort more or less complete? Or are you still testing downspacing in the Marcellus?

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We will continue to test not only how tight we can get locations, and Phil has a couple downspace opportunities or wells that we look at. But we'll also continue to explore with stage loading and spaces, spacing between clusters as part of our effort
componenttext: Yes. We will continue to test not only how tight we can get locations, and Phil has a couple downspace opportunities or wells that we look at. But we'll also continue to explore with stage loading and spaces, spacing between clusters as part of our efforts to see how we can enhance the program. One of the July period for Cabot at our board meetings is opportunity for our geologist to stand before the board and talk about our exploration projects, ideas that we have, and we do have some, and we did present several to our board on Wednesday. But one of the things also the technical group has done in the North has -- is taking a step back. We have a huge database, as you can surmise, and look at the entire space and determine what we might do different with a blank piece of paper, starting over to try to look at all the different aspects, all the way from planning areas, steering, penetration rates, how we initiate fracs, how we bring back the wells. All of that is being scrutinized in a project-orientated fashion that I imagine Phil would come back and discuss at a later date. Phil, do you want to make any sentimental [indiscernible]?

So again, it's an ongoing effort here to continue to optimize our potential out there.

componenttext: And one of the things also is not only looking at the upper Marcellus and all the way through the Purcell or our Marcellus. But the complexity of the geology, looking at the relationship to production profiles within some of the proximity to some of the larger faulting systems and also looking at a couple of different zones in the section that we think hold for what I would couch today as exploratory promise.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right, Ericson. I don't have any additional remarks. But just to reemphasize that we are extremely pleased with the operational side of our program. We are building into the infrastructure build-out, starting the early stages of some excitement about
componenttext:
All right, Ericson. I don't have any additional remarks. But just to reemphasize that we are extremely pleased with the operational side of our program. We are building into the infrastructure build-out, starting the early stages of some excitement about seeing some tangible results in that area. And I think it's going to be fun for our operating group to now diligently start being able to use their talents, secure the services and equipment and start a very diligent process in building these significant volumes. 
If you look out there in the space, I don't know if any other company that has an opportunity and the rock to be able -- and the balance sheet to be able to grow production, double production in the next couple of years and have the benefits to -- and shareholders as Cabot does. 
So thank you for your interest, and we are excited about presenting our 5-year plan to our board in October. And we do anticipate offering maybe a little bit more color either on October or February, we haven't made that call, of a little bit longer outlook for what Cabot has to offer. 
So thanks again, and look forward to the next quarterly call.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the Cabot Oil & Gas  Corporation Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call and webcast. [Operator Instructions] Please note, this event is being recorded.I would now like to turn the conference over to Mr. Dan Dinges, Chai
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to the Cabot Oil & Gas  Corporation Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call and webcast. [Operator Instructions] Please note, this event is being recorded.
I would now like to turn the conference over to Mr. Dan Dinges, Chairman, CEO and President. Please go ahead.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Gary, and good morning. Thank you for joining us today for Cabot's Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. With me today are several members of Cabot's executive management team. Trust that everyone has had the opportunity to review our press release
componenttext:
Thank you, Gary, and good morning. Thank you for joining us today for Cabot's Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. With me today are several members of Cabot's executive management team. Trust that everyone has had the opportunity to review our press release from this morning. Additionally, we have posted a presentation to our website, something new, that I will directly reference on the call this morning. This presentation highlights our financial and operational results from the quarter, as well as provide an updated outlook for the company's plans for 2017 and beyond. 
However, before we get started, I'd first like to move to Slide 2 of the presentation, which addresses our forward-looking statements. Please note that we will make forward-looking statements based on current expectation this morning. Also, some of our comments may reference non-GAAP financial measures, forward-looking statements and other disclaimers, as well as reconciliations to the most directly comparable GAAP financial measures are provided in both the earnings release and this presentation.
Moving on to the third quarter financial highlights on Page 3. Cabot once again generated positive free cash flow for the quarter, while growing equivalent production 6% year-over-year, despite our production being impacted by downstream maintenance projects and unplanned upstream gathering downtime during the quarter. We remain committed to generating return-focused measured growth within cash flow. And this quarter, we successfully executed on this plan. While much has been made recently about a widening of regional differentials, we actually recorded our best pre-hedged natural gas realization since the first quarter of 2015 when the average NYMEX price was $0.17 higher than this past quarter. Our pre-hedge realization of $1.80 per MCF were 7% better than the comparable quarter last year and 16% higher sequentially relative to the second quarter. 
Our cost structure continued to improve during the quarter with cash costs, operating costs declining 13% year-over-year. We expect this trend to continue over the next few years as we leverage our operational scale to further improve our cost structure. Our financial position remains strong with over $500 million of cash on hand, approximately $1.7 billion of available commitments on our undrawn credit facility and a net debt-to-EBITDAX ratio of 1.9x at quarter end.
Moving on to Slide 4, where we have outlined the significant decline in our drilling and completion costs and our LOE, which is a direct impact of efficiency gains our operational teams had accomplished over the past few years. They have done an outstanding job with this. While it is possible that we could see some upward pressure on service costs, I anticipate that we will continue to see a downward trend in our overall cost structure as we become even more efficient in our operations.
On Slide 5, we have outlined the results of a few reduced space pilots that we have been testing in our Marcellus operating area. This is a interesting area for us. The graphs on this slide represent 4 different pads, where we completed 1 well with our Gen 3 completion design and 1 offset well with our Gen 4 completion design. We have experienced overall a 20% uplift in cumulative production from the Gen-4 wells. As a result, we have decided to implement this completion design for all of our wells, going forward, beginning in the fourth quarter of this year. As we typically do each year, we will wait until our year-end reserve audit before making any changes to our EUR. However, as you can see by the numbers, we are very excited about what this could mean for our industry-leading well productivity going forward.
On Slide 6, we have laid out our capital program for 2017, which includes the program-wide implementation of the Gen 4 completion design in the Marcellus. As we alluded to on the second quarter call, we are targeting 5% to 10% production growth in 2017. This is based on total program spending of $625 million, which includes $575 million at the E&P capital, and another $50 million for our equity investments in the Atlantic Sunrise and Constitution pipelines. $535 million or 93% of E&P capital is earmarked for drilling and completion activity associated with the 70 well -- net wells we plan to drill and the 75 net wells we plan to complete next year. 79% of the drill and complete capital will be directed to the Marcellus, and the remaining 21% will be directed to the Eagle Ford, where the program is focused on maintaining leasehold, holding oil the volumes flat and generating a cash flow neutral operating program. We have allocated $225 million for maintenance capital in the Marcellus and Eagle Ford, which is the amount of capital needed to hold our anticipated 2016 exit production flat throughout 2017, and also allows us to meet all our obligatory operating commitments to maintain our leasehold.
This flat production profile for the year would imply growth at the low end of our production growth guidance range. The remaining capital for the year provides the productive capacity needed to meet or exceed the high end of our 2017 guidance range, assuming price realizations are at levels that generate strong return for Cabot, while also allowing us to build the backlog necessary to meet our production targets in '18, when we anticipate a significant amount of new takeaway capacity being placed in service.
Slide 7 highlights the well level economics on the average well we plan to drill in 2017. Even in a low price environment, both our assets generate strong returns. However, from a capital allocation perspective, you can see why the Marcellus continues to receive the lion's share of capital. At a $2 realized price, our wells generate a rate of return over 100%, highlighting the world-class asset we have in Northeast Pennsylvania. I would also highlight that the well cost on this slide includes facility costs, and also reflects our current view of the service cost environment for 2017. Additionally, the Marcellus well costs include the incremental stages and the corresponding increase in well cost for the Gen 4 completion design.
Moving on to Slide 8. We have highlighted our natural gas price exposure by index for 2017, while it is no surprise that we have a significant amount of exposure to in-basin pricing during '17. [ph] As we await the addition of new takeaway project in 2018, we have taken numerous steps to mitigate the potential for downside pricing risk next year. We have about 12% of our natural gas production tied to NYMEX, and we have hedged the majority of that exposure at an average floor price of approximately $3.10 per Mcf. We have also locked in another 21% of our volumes with fixed-price contracts at an average price of $2.15. The majority of these volumes would typically be tied to the Northeast PA index that have seen significantly worse pricing over the last few years. As a result, we believe fixing these volumes at prices that generate the high returns we highlighted on the previous slide is a prudent decision.
Regarding our balance sheet. As I mentioned at the beginning of the call, we have an extremely strong financial position with a significant amount of flexibility given our cash on cash and availability under our credit facility. You'll notice that our highest cost debt matures in 2018, leaving us with a much lower weighted average interest rate subsequent to those maturities.
Okay, moving to Slide 9. In light of all of the recent news flow regarding Atlantic Sunrise and other infrastructure projects in Appalachia, on Slide 9, we have provided a brief update on all the projects that we are participating in over the next few years. For today's call, I plan only to specifically address a few of the projects, however, all of these projects are important steps towards realizing our long-term initiatives and value creation from our Marcellus assets. Our 2 infrastructure projects in the power market, the Moxie Freedom power plant and the Lackawanna Energy Center power plant, are currently under full scale construction. Both facilities are on track to be completed by June 2018, with the Lackawanna project phasing in between June and December 2018. I remind everyone that this new local demand of approximately 400 million cubic foot per day is essentially tied to our gathering system, and eliminates the need to commit to expensive [ph] long-term firm transportation agreements.
Overall, we anticipate the net backs on these volumes to be some of the best in our portfolio. Tennessee Orien project, in which we are a sole supplier, recently received a favorable environmental assessment from the FERC, and is slated to begin construction in January 2017. We have approximately 135 million per day on this project, and anticipate the netbacks will be accretive to in-basin netbacks.
Moving on to Atlantic Sunrise. As you're aware, we recently had a slight setback with the FERC moving the timing of the issuance of the final environmental impact statement from October to December in order to accommodate comments from landowners regarding 2 minor route alternatives, totaling 1.4 miles. While disappointed that this decision has resulted in a delay of in-service date to mid-2018, we believe the decision was prudent, and that at the end of the day, the Atlantic Sunrise route will ultimately be ensured of a full and complete record. And as you're all aware, in this environment, we simply want to get it done right, particularly concerning the route. You will notice that all these projects have the potential to be placed in service during 2018, highlighting what an inflection year 2018 can be for Cabot.
Not only do we believe that 2018 is going to be a strong year for us, but also additional infrastructure is needed for PA and the nation, and I'd refer you to the Pennsylvania Governor will [ph] support that position referenced in Williams' press release this morning.
Moving to Slide 10, highlights the cumulative impact of all the projects we have highlighted on the previous slide, allowing us to potentially double our gross production out of the Marcellus to 4 BCF per day. Clearly, there has been a lot of questions around constitution, given the ongoing appeal process. But even if you exclude constitution from the conversation, we would be able to produce 3.5 Bcf per day with these existing projects that are on the slate once all the new projects are online. We remain optimistic that Constitution will be built and that will -- we will continue to assess new outlets that enable us to grow our production higher than the levels outlined on the slide. However, even if we were able to hold the production flat at 3.5 Bcf per day, we believe a highly capital efficient asset base provides a unique value proposition via the free cash flow yield.
At a range of realized prices between $2.50 and $3 per Mcf, our standalone Marcellus asset generates between $1.1 billion and $1.6 billion pretax free cash flow, and we will have the inventory to hold production flat at those levels until 2037.
Slide 11 illustrates the change in how our market -- Marcellus production between now and 4Q 2018, which is when we expect to have the majority of this new infrastructure online. As you can see that our exposure in the Northeast PA price point, Leidy, Tennessee, Millennium, reduces significantly, while our exposure to NYMEX, the D.C. market area and the newbuild power generation facilities increases significantly. While we fully believe that in-price -- in-basin pricing will improve dramatically during this period, as major projects like Atlantic Sunrise and PennEast are built, even if you assume there are no changes in NYMEX or regional basis differentials between Q4 '16 and Q4 '18, the addition of our new takeaway capacity would improve realized prices by greater than $0.50 per Mcf on all of our volumes. Based on the midpoint of our expectation of Q4 2018 production range, a $0.50 uplift in realized prices would represent over $450 million uplift in cash flows on an annualized basis. 
Moving to Slide 12. Slide 12 highlights our planned production growth through 2018 and some of the anticipated byproducts of this plan based on current strip pricing. As I already highlighted earlier on the call, we plan to generate 5% to 10% production growth in 2017. And based on today's strip, we will generate a meaningful amount of free cash flow even after accounting for pipeline investments and dividends. You can also see that we expect to delever by 1 term, resulting in year-end 2017 target leverage ratio of 1x.
We also highlighted a preliminary 2018 production growth range of 15% to 25%, based on a program that also generates positive free cash flow at today's strip. Ultimately, where we land within that range will be a function of the timing of the in-service of the takeaway projects we highlighted previously and what the expectations are for in-basin prices during this period of time. However, based on the target in-service date we laid out on Slide 9 and our current expectations of where our local prices will be in 2018, we feel very comfortable that we will be able to deliver on production growth within the range, while generating free cash flow, delevering, reducing cash costs and increasing cash margins.
While we have not included 2019 growth expectations at this time, given the lineup of new takeaway projects slated for mid- to late-2018 in-service date, it is reasonable to assume 2019 will be another year of robust growth for Cabot Oil & Gas.
And Gary, with that, I will now open the lines up for Q&A.

componenttext: Okay. Well, Jeff is a expert in marketing area, and he sits poised beside me on each of these calls to answer all of the questions that we have in regard to marketing. And as you know, I'll just preface this by saying that basis has been extremely volatile from the first Q, second Q, and then rolling into the third Q of 2017. We see a lot of volatility, and we anticipate that volatility to continue into the future to have a fair way of where we think the differentials are going to be. It's not easy, but we've given it a shot.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, Drew. This is Jeff. Obviously, we didn't get off to a good start with October basis, but what we tried to do is just highlight in the guidance and in the slides exactly what our exposures are to each particular index. So based on the pie chart you s
componenttext: Okay, Drew. This is Jeff. Obviously, we didn't get off to a good start with October basis, but what we tried to do is just highlight in the guidance and in the slides exactly what our exposures are to each particular index. So based on the pie chart you see and on the guidance, you can [ph] get a pretty good idea of where the exposure lies, and it's been up and down all year long, and we had a really bad first quarter because of weather. It tightened up [indiscernible] Q2. And we have another semi-blowout, I would say, in [ph] Q3. But basically, it's strengthening on the cash market. We have a very good year on cash in terms of -- I wouldn't say very good year. I'll tell you, better than what we expected with the weather and storage conditions. But if you review the pie chart closely, you'll see the exposures.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. We have -- we certainly have tested more than 4 pads. We have, on the 4 pads, we illustrated it was -- we thought a -- the best apples-and-apples comparison where we had side-by-side heading in the same direction spaced accordingly and growing through
componenttext: No. We have -- we certainly have tested more than 4 pads. We have, on the 4 pads, we illustrated it was -- we thought a -- the best apples-and-apples comparison where we had side-by-side heading in the same direction spaced accordingly and growing through the same geology, the Gen 3 and Gen 4. But we have -- in addition to these, we have approximately 20 other wells that we have [ph] history with the Gen 4 completions. What we don't have, we have -- we can extrapolate on those with the results, but we didn't have -- we don't have on all of those the exact side-by-side apples-and-apples comparison. But we did see positive results in the majority of the Gen 4 completions that we have implemented.

componenttext: Yes. We look at value kind of lined on commodity, though we have expertise in both oil and gas by virtue of our 2 regions, we're looking at the value proposition, looking at what can compete for our capital and provide what our strategy is, and that is very deliver a growth with a high return profile to it. So I think the activity in the Eagle Ford, I think activity in the Marcellus could be a reflection of maybe how the activity in the Permian Bax group has gone with the valuations in those particular basins. But when you look at our ongoing line of business, we're not that inquisitive. However, we are informed with the transactions that taken place by either being in data rooms or doing our own evaluation of the transactions that have taken place. But primary consideration on our valuation is value.

componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask you on Slide 5. Is it correct that you have done [ph] in 2 years of Fortune data as the slide implies? Or is that an -- oops, shorter data set as has been extrapolated out?
componenttext: I wanted to ask you on Slide 5. Is it correct that you have done [ph] in 2 years of Fortune data as the slide implies? Or is that an -- oops, shorter data set as has been extrapolated out?

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. Back to the comment I made about different tweaks and trying different things that make a lot of sense. We have a significant term on these -- the definition of our Gen 4. We also, though, through our Gen 1 through Gen 4 have different modifications w
componenttext: No. Back to the comment I made about different tweaks and trying different things that make a lot of sense. We have a significant term on these -- the definition of our Gen 4. We also, though, through our Gen 1 through Gen 4 have different modifications within that definition of each one of those we have employed. In this particular case, we wanted to make sure that we felt good about the long-term profile that we didn't get the near well bore spike on high IPs and then have a falloff later that yielded a reduction in the return. And keep in mind, early on, when we were doing these completions, the cost of completion was higher early on. So you had to be certain early on that you were getting and efficiency uplift in the completions before you were going to spend the money to go forward. And what we've -- a couple of things have happened now. Not only has the costs gone down on the completions, which yields even better return profile, but as you can see on these slides that as you go -- you're growing out into -- deeper into the amount of days on production, you're actually seeing a widening in the type curve that we have for Gen 3 and the type curve we're realizing on the Gen 4 wells, which is a very good positive.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right, okay. Perfect. And then finally, if I could ask kind of a higher level question regarding Constitution. You actually have 2 actions going. You got the appeal on the Second Circuit and then you got a separate action in the Northern District. I was j
componenttext: Right, okay. Perfect. And then finally, if I could ask kind of a higher level question regarding Constitution. You actually have 2 actions going. You got the appeal on the Second Circuit and then you got a separate action in the Northern District. I was just curious, are you anymore confident in one approach than the other? And ultimately, and I know this is a tough question but it's [indiscernible] same way at every pipeline resistance that we're getting these days. Ultimately, if the actions are somehow unsuccessful, is there any indication that FERC is going to step up and find the exercise as regulatory authority?

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, great question, and I can just make a macro comment in regard to the latter part, Jeffrey. And I'll comment, then I'll turn it to Jeff to get some color on the Constitution on the 2 courts. But we're faced with a challenge on the energy space. All -
componenttext: Well, great question, and I can just make a macro comment in regard to the latter part, Jeffrey. And I'll comment, then I'll turn it to Jeff to get some color on the Constitution on the 2 courts. But we're faced with a challenge on the energy space. All -- not just Atlantic Sunrise, Constitution but access and other pipelines that are -- and infrastructure that are going to be challenged by activists that, quiet frankly, just don't want to have carbon in the energy mix. I think it's clear that hydrocarbons are going to be part of the energy mix and without a solution for many decades to come. So the argument in the fight today is real to those activists. But from a practicality standpoint, we're going to need the infrastructure to service the demand needs and the demand growth that is perceived in all of these communities. FERC is certainly challenged with the regulatory side and the legal battles that are in front of it on a regular basis. We've seen in their decision process additional caution that they have implemented in their review process. I think it's prudent for that review process. But to your point about moving forward and moving the country forward with a need and the public need is also part of their fiduciary role also, and I think they take that very seriously. So we're getting better as an industry to be able to answer in advance all the challenges that are being placed before us by the antis and those that want to stop the pipelines and infrastructures. We'll continue to get better on the front end to answer all the questions. And hopefully answering those questions on the front end will mitigate some of the delays we've seen in some of these projects as we move forward. I will -- just before I turn it to Jeff, I will make one distinction. When you look at access pipeline and some of the protests that are going on out there, it challenges the local authorities to challenge the rule of law on what is being implemented and what is being actually allowed to take place up there. And looking at Atlantic Sunrise, Atlantic Sunrise is a Pennsylvania pipeline. Atlantic Sunrise is a pipeline that, for particularly [indiscernible] position, we see a need on the other hand of Atlantic Sunrise once it is constructed. But more importantly, there are areas in the -- in Northeast Pennsylvania that wealthy owners in Northeast Pennsylvania are getting virtually no return for the royalties because the differentials have been so punitive up there in that particular part of the area. When that happens, the state of Pennsylvania certainly does not see any return to the coppers in the form of revenue and taxes because of the significant punities that have been in that area because of the gas-on-gas competition. So in referencing Governor's Will letter, I think he recognizes that getting an infrastructure, particularly something as near term and as impactful as Atlantic Sunrise, has a significant value to Pennsylvania and its constituents to be able to help its shortfall in its budget process. So we think all of that is part of the equation and another reason why Constitution -- excuse me, Atlantic Sunrise should move forward. Long-winded, Jeffrey, but I'll turn it to Jeff to make a comment on Constitution.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. What we certainly do like the Second Circuit action, the appeal is very simple. The -- if you read the briefs at all, you'll see the case that we've laid out as, in our opinion, very strong, very clear. The -- even the affidavit and testimonials at
componenttext: Okay. What we certainly do like the Second Circuit action, the appeal is very simple. The -- if you read the briefs at all, you'll see the case that we've laid out as, in our opinion, very strong, very clear. The -- even the affidavit and testimonials at the end on the conversations between DET -- excuse me, DEC and our environmental folks is very clear. We read the respondent's brief as well. It was, again our opinion, number is strong. Of course, we filed a reply to that brief. It's now in the hands of the court and quite frankly, the schedule is I think very favorable. We'll have the oral arguments in November and then we hope to get a reply by the court in the spring. All that said, we still like the action in the northern district as well, where we think it's a very strong case. It's a little more complicated, and it's [indiscernible] for the duration of that particular action. We would like it probably equally with the appeal. So we're down 2 paths. We think they're both very strong, and we'll see what happens.

componenttext: I'm going to answer first and then turn it to Phil. First, on the latter part, do I think this is incremental reserves or acceleration? We think this is all incremental reserves. Keep in mind that the spacing on these are the spacing that we have a significant amount of data on through all of our drilling out there. And the spacing on these and where we've laid the laterals, we think it's all incremental reserves. We're comfortable with that. I'll let Phil answer the rest of it.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We obviously have -- Brian, we obviously have purposely left off specifics, but -- and the specifics we left off was to mitigate The Street getting out ahead of us on trying to preempt our year-end reserve review. Our year-end reserve review and audit is
componenttext: We obviously have -- Brian, we obviously have purposely left off specifics, but -- and the specifics we left off was to mitigate The Street getting out ahead of us on trying to preempt our year-end reserve review. Our year-end reserve review and audit is we go into excruciating detail. We do 100% audit, and we'll come out with that after the end of the year. But in our comment made to talk about the 20% plus efficiency gain was designed to give a little bit of color, but we have left off some of the details just to allow us to do the year-end reserves without setting expectations that would get out in front of the actual.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then, I guess, shifting to the free cash flow that you're expecting beginning next year and continuing, and this is not a new question but you talked about M&A a little bit earlier. And just wondered if you could give us your latest thoughts on how th
componenttext: And then, I guess, shifting to the free cash flow that you're expecting beginning next year and continuing, and this is not a new question but you talked about M&A a little bit earlier. And just wondered if you could give us your latest thoughts on how that free cash flow gets allocated? And whether you use that for debt pay down? Whether you use that for returning to shareholders? Or whether that goes into a costs for potential M&A.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, all of the above is still consideration at this point in time, Brian. We have and will have conversations in the boardroom about dividend policy. We certainly have a good balance sheet at this stage, and I know Scott gets a little concerned about to
componenttext: Well, all of the above is still consideration at this point in time, Brian. We have and will have conversations in the boardroom about dividend policy. We certainly have a good balance sheet at this stage, and I know Scott gets a little concerned about too low of a debt levels. But when you look at the value consideration on either looking at other projects could allocate capital, that's part of our internal effort to continue to evaluate all of the opportunities that are out there today. But we again look at that with value consideration as probably 1, 2 and 3 and knowing that we have such a world-class [ph] return profile for our Marcellus. We want to make sure that if we do have projects outside, that it's going to be somewhat competitive where we might allocate that free cash and could be favorably with our Marcellus acquisition. So in this low commodity price environment, still having efficiency gains in a lot of areas, including our Marcellus. We are penalized by the Northeast differentials that we experienced up there. We think we have a fix that is been split out from what we originally had anticipated, extremely frustrating from our perspective that we are moving gas in the range that we're moving it in. But we do think we have some daylight coming down the road and with that daylight, I don't think we'll be able to find a project that is better than the Marcellus. We're just looking for one that will compete favorably if, in fact, we go that route.

componenttext: Well, let me rephrase the answer then just to be clear. The available capacity reaches the point that our production can access. The price is just not what it used to be, so we're seeing a deterioration of prices at [indiscernible] and into the West as well. So in that respect, it's just not worth spending the money to get additional capacity in this marketplace until we see some strengthening in our basis in other areas.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, thank you, Gary, and thank you all for the questions. We remain very excited about the company's future and the opportunity set that lies ahead of us for generating long-term shareholder value. While the last years have been an extremely frustrating
componenttext: Well, thank you, Gary, and thank you all for the questions. We remain very excited about the company's future and the opportunity set that lies ahead of us for generating long-term shareholder value. While the last years have been an extremely frustrating, not being able to [indiscernible] infrastructure in the ground, we continue to work through ongoing delays in the infrastructure buildout in Appalachia, and we do remain confident that better days are ahead of us, particularly in 2018 and certainly beyond. Despite the low commodity price environment and the forecast that we've given, we think we will managed through the differentials, and we think that we will continue to be able to generate strong returns, grow production, while maintaining our balance sheet, grow reserves at an all-time low-binding costs and certainly significantly reduce our cost structure through the efficiency gains. So thank you to all the shareholders that we have out there, particularly to our long-term shareholders, for their continued patience, and I look forward to speaking with the group again in February. So with that, Gary, that concludes my remarks.
